column1: while submitting a transaction to ledger throwing timeout exception from fabric-gateway
column32: Hi i have used bevel setup for running my fabric network, currently while submitting the transaction from fabric-gateway we are facing timeout even though it has been sucessfully submitted to both ledger and peer sucessfully, has confirmed based on timestamp and logs. please take this on high priority we are facing this issue in production
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Support for Hyperledger Fabric Batch Size
column32:
Hey Team,

Could not find Hyperledger Fabric Project. So, raising an issue under Blockchain Explorer.

We want to insert bulk data in Hyperledger in a single transaction using application created on Java SDK.

We are processing data in batches of 1000 Records in a Scheduler and Scheduler runs after every 1 min interval.

*We are Facing issue as follows:*

java.lang.Exception: io.grpc.StatusRuntimeException: RESOURCE_EXHAUSTED: gRPC message exceeds maximum size 4194304: 7544228

 

Also, after the above error we made a setup of new fabric network by making changes in *configtx.yaml*

+*Before:*+
    BatchTimeout: 2s
    BatchSize:
        MaxMessageCount: 10
        AbsoluteMaxBytes: 99 MB
        PreferredMaxBytes: 512 KB
 
+*After:*+
    BatchTimeout: 2s
    BatchSize:
        MaxMessageCount: 1000
        AbsoluteMaxBytes: 99 MB
        PreferredMaxBytes: 99 MB
 
Though we have made the above changes, it seems no affect in Batch Size. 
 
Please assist!
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Chaincode package issue
column32:
Error: error getting chaincode deployment : 'go list' failed with: package chaincodes is not in GOROOT (/usr/local/go/src/chaincodes): exit status 1

 

When trying to execute the package command the above error is getting generated. The version of network setup is 2.2 . Even the GOROOT is pointing to /usr/local/go/src/chaincodes.  Still getting the above error. Can anyone suggest some solutions for it ?

column1: Array of data not getting written into the blockchain
column32: We are trying to write the array of data into the blockchain network through NODE API.  The version of blockchain network we are using is 2.2 . But the array data is not getting written. So to test that we were trying to find out if the data is getting into chaincode or not.We are not able to print values/log from the external chaincode as well. Could anyone suggest a solution for this issue?

column1: Fabric Java Applications cannot be executed because of dependency bug with bouncycastle
column32:
Somehow i cannot set this bug for the fabric project but only for BE or IR so please move it to fabric.

When executing a fabric java sdk app, for example the application from the fabric-samples under the path fabric-samples/commercial-paper/organization/digibank/application-java the following error occurs:
{code:java}
// java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: 'void org.bouncycastle.asn1.DERSequenceGenerator.addObject(org.bouncycastle.asn1.ASN1Primitive)'
    at org.hyperledger.fabric.sdk.security.CryptoPrimitives.ecdsaSignToBytes (CryptoPrimitives.java:765)
    at org.hyperledger.fabric.sdk.security.CryptoPrimitives.sign (CryptoPrimitives.java:782)
    at org.hyperledger.fabric.sdk.identity.X509SigningIdentity.sign (X509SigningIdentity.java:23)
    at org.hyperledger.fabric.sdk.transaction.TransactionContext.sign (TransactionContext.java:180)
    at org.hyperledger.fabric.sdk.transaction.TransactionContext.signByteString (TransactionContext.java:184)
    at org.hyperledger.fabric.sdk.Channel.getSignedProposal (Channel.java:2961)
    at org.hyperledger.fabric.sdk.Channel.getConfigBlock (Channel.java:931)
    at org.hyperledger.fabric.sdk.Channel.getConfigBlock (Channel.java:907)
    at org.hyperledger.fabric.sdk.Channel.parseConfigBlock (Channel.java:1964)
    at org.hyperledger.fabric.sdk.Channel.loadCACertificates (Channel.java:1801)
    at org.hyperledger.fabric.sdk.Channel.initialize (Channel.java:1222)
    at org.hyperledger.fabric.gateway.impl.NetworkImpl.initializeChannel (NetworkImpl.java:59)
    at org.hyperledger.fabric.gateway.impl.NetworkImpl.<init> (NetworkImpl.java:50)
    at org.hyperledger.fabric.gateway.impl.GatewayImpl.getNetwork (GatewayImpl.java:252)
    at org.digibank.Buy.main (Buy.java:53)
    at org.codehaus.mojo.exec.ExecJavaMojo$1.run (ExecJavaMojo.java:254)
    at java.lang.Thread.run (Thread.java:833){code}
I'm using latest java temurin-17.0.1, maven 3.8.4, fabric-gateway-java 2.2.1 and fabric-chaincode-shim 2.4.1. 
 fabric-chaincode-shim is importing org.bouncycastle:bcpkix-jdk15on:jar:1.62:compile
 and org.bouncycastle:bcprov-jdk15on:jar:1.62:compile. I've tried manually adding all later bouncycastle versions up to 1.70 but they give other errors. I also tried using earlier versions of chaincode-shim down to 2.2.0 where another dependency conflict arises. earlyier versions produce the same error.

column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column171:
02/Apr/21 2:50 PM;loveband77;I hope someone can fix the cause of the problem, and I have to keep working until the day comes, so I'm going to share a temporary method.

This error seems to be coming from sync.js.
 When this error occurs, the explorer container process does not work normally.
 Therefore, the script was changed to run pm2 so that the explorer service does not die even if an error occurs.

Whenever it is restarted, sync.js runs, and that process uses a lot of memory.
 We have allocated a large amount of memory to that process and container.
 And I added it to the volume so that pm2 can be accessed from the container.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 docker-compose.yaml (some)
 ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 explorer.mynetwork.com:
     image: hyperledger/explorer:latest

    command: sh c "/mnt/bin/pm2 start /opt/explorer/app/main.js -i 2 --node-args='max-old-space-size=1024' && /mnt/bin/pm2 start /opt/explorer/app/sync.js -i 1 --node-args='-max-old-space-size=10240' --max-memory-restart=10240M && tail -f /dev/null"

    volumes:
         - /data/lib_pm2/pm2:/mnt 

    mem_limit: 10240m;;;

column1: UI Link To Transaction
column32: I want to be able to give transaction links by tx id to end users so that they can check the validity of the transaction on Blockchain Explorer UI. With the current implementation, it kinda seems not possible to do so. (I couldn't find any link that directs to tx pop up.) Please consider implementing this feature. (Something like etherscan)

column174:
10/Aug/20 5:58 PM;nekia;At this moment, I guess it's a kind of configuration issue. Please do double check your environment with the following aspects.
 * Set true to client.tlsEnable in your connection profile. Please refer [here|https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README-CONFIG.md#enable-tls] for detail
 * URL of each peer in your connection profile starts with 'grpcs://'. Please refer [here|https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README-CONFIG.md#enable-tls] for detail
 * Cleanup persistent data. Please refer [here|https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README-CONFIG.md#run-hyperledger-explorer-using-docker-compose] for detail

And please share the following information if possible
 * Explorer version
 * Fabric version
 * Connection profile you're using ;;;
column175:
10/Aug/20 6:27 PM;csquan;[~nekia] thank you for your reply,I have run first-network and explorer ,it work well.

so I try to deploy explorer to another network:balance-transfer.

All steps almost same.

first,run balance-transfer network.

second,copy crypto dir from {color:#172b4d}balance-transfer{color} to explorer local dir.

then edit config.json and docker-compose.yaml(path and name of sk and certs files).

last,I had copy app/platform/fabric/connect-profile/balance-transfer.json to local c{color:#172b4d}onnection-profile dir{color} .

also I have set tls of client to true,since {color:#172b4d}balance-transfer{color} network enable tls.

my fabric images version 1.4.1,

and explorer is update to master.

 ;;;

11/Aug/20 7:28 PM;csquan;[~nfrunza] [~nekia]

The difference between first-network and balance-transfer in fabric-samples is :

first-network can cryptogen certs files ,though balance-transfer can also generete,but it can not use ,because use that file network can not start .

so balance supply official crypto-dir and network can start.

but that dir explorer can not use ,always ssl error.

does there anyone who success deploy explorer in docker use balance-transfer ?

doubt it.

column199: 12/Aug/20 11:22 PM;nekia;Whatever your local node version is, explorer container uses node v10. And at this moment, I'm not sure if there is any compatibility issue between a specific node version and *first-network*.;;;
column200:
18/Aug/20 12:00 PM;csquan;[~nekia]  as you said,explorer docker use node v10 ,no business of my acutual local machine node version.

I want to know why docker can not start normally?

I had checkout 0.3.9.4 and node version is v8.11.3, run ./start.sh and explorer start normally which connect to my local balance-transfer network.

so,there may be something wrong in docker version?

 ;;;
column201:
18/Aug/20 4:12 PM;nekia;Unfortunately I don't know. But as far as looking at the following results, it seems not to be a problem of Explorer.
 * balance-transfer example doesn't work with node v10 or later
 * Both error happened when you tried running the latest Explorer docker (using node v10) with balance-transfer and one I had when just trying to bring up balance-transfer with node v10 or later are identical

 

Although I don't know there is easy way to do that, if you update credential artifacts for balance-transfer committed in its repo, you might have a progress. ;;;
column203:
19/Aug/20 9:12 PM;nekia;fabric-sdk-node(fabric-network package) requires node v10 or later and the latest Explorer depends on fabric-sdk-node. So the latest Explorer can't work with node v8.


FYI
If you re-generate all channel artifacts of balance-transfer, everything is going to be fine. Now I can bring up balance-transfer demo with node v10.22.0.

{noformat}
cd ~/dev/hyperledger/fabric-samples/balance-transfer/artifacts/channel
rm -rf crypto-config genesis.block mychannel.tx Org1MSPanchors.tx Org2MSPanchors.tx
cryptogen generate --config cryptogen.yaml 
configtxgen -profile TwoOrgsOrdererGenesis -channelID testchainid -outputBlock ./genesis.block 
configtxgen -profile TwoOrgsChannel -outputCreateChannelTx ./mychannel.tx -channelID mychannel
configtxgen -profile TwoOrgsChannel -outputAnchorPeersUpdate ./Org1MSPanchors.tx -channelID mychannel -asOrg Org1MSP
configtxgen -profile TwoOrgsChannel -outputAnchorPeersUpdate ./Org2MSPanchors.tx -channelID mychannel -asOrg Org2MSP
{noformat}

 ;;;

column1: Docker image publish fails
column32:
Looks like the latest commit broke the docker publishing
commit e0d4f367f67a7887b0fc15bb7d677180342e777a.


The docker image creation script runs docker_explorer.sh

# Build blockchain-explorer images
docker_Build_Images() {
     # build "explorer & explorer-db" images
     ./deploy_explorer.sh
}

# list docker images
docker images | grep hyperledger

docker_Explorer_Push() {
   # Clone blockchain-explorer
   clone_Blockchain_Explorer
   # Call to build blockchain-explorer images
   docker_Build_Images
 for IMAGES in ${IMAGES_LIST[*]}; do
   # Tag with latest & ($PUSH_VERSION)
   docker tag $ORG_NAME/$IMAGES $ORG_NAME/$IMAGES:$1
   docker tag $ORG_NAME/$IMAGES $ORG_NAME/$IMAGES
   echo "------> Push blockchain-explorer Images to hyperledger dockerhub Repository"
   docker push $ORG_NAME/$IMAGES:$1
   docker push $ORG_NAME/$IMAGES
 done
}


Could you please check this log https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/view/blockchain-explorer/job/blockchain-explorer-release-job-x86_64/8/console
Are we not building images from the latest commit?
See these lines, https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/deploy_explorer.sh#L137-L144
I think it's trying to execute docker run command but it's trying to pull these images..

 * Even in release 0.3.8, the same problem happened. I have not looked at the reason why there is difference between results of these release.
 ** release 0.3.9(FAILURE)
 [https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/view/blockchain-explorer/job/blockchain-explorer-release-job-x86_64/7/console]

 [https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/view/blockchain-explorer/job/blockchain-explorer-release-job-x86_64/6/console]
 * I'm not sure why using deploy_explorer.sh to build docker images
 ** As far as looking at BE-481 , using each dockerfile (./Dockerfile, ./postgres-Dockerfile) is suggested at that time.

I think we need to do some reconfiguration for job in CI.;;;
column172:
12/Feb/19 7:28 PM;nekia;One of the easy options is adding a new mode to deploy_explorer.sh as below and changing *jjb/blockchain-explorer/shell/include-raw-push-explorer-docker-images.sh* to call this script with *--build* argument.

{code:}
$ git diff deploy_explorer.sh
diff --git a/deploy_explorer.sh b/deploy_explorer.sh
index b57a8fc..51432ac 100755
--- a/deploy_explorer.sh
+++ b/deploy_explorer.sh
@@ -232,6 +232,10 @@ function main(){
         stop_database
         docker rmi $(docker images -q ${fabric_explorer_db_tag})
         docker rmi $(docker images -q ${fabric_explorer_tag})
+    elif [ "$MODE" == "--build" ]; then
+      echo "Building Hyperledger Fabric explorer / explorer-db containers..."
+        deploy_build_explorer
+        deploy_build_database
     elser
         deploy "$@"
     fi
{code}

Although we have already been trying to use docker-compose for running containers instead (BE-515), if choose this option, we would not be able to delete this script.

I think, the best option is creating a brand new script only for building docker images to avoid confusion and deleting deploy_explorer.sh ( Of course we also need to switch script called from include-raw-push-explorer-docker-images.sh).

[~nfrunza];;;
column173: 13/Feb/19 12:19 AM;nfrunza;[~nekia] I see, thanks for troubleshooting, please go ahead, and create a new script, I'll contact [~rameshthoomu] when you're ready to update in CI/CD;;;
column174:
13/Feb/19 4:44 PM;nekia;I could build docker image successfully in my local environment, and it seems to be working fine unless applying the change for upgrading HLF 1.4.

 

After applying the changes, explorer seems to fail to discover orderer and peers in FabricClient.initializeChannelFromDiscover(). This problem doesn't happen when I run explorer without docker. 
h3.  Environment
 * balance-transfer network (release-1.4)
 * fabric 1.4.0
 * Docker image ( locally built )
 ** [^build_docker_image.sh]
 *** ^Save this script in root directory of explorer and run it to build docker images in your environment.^
 * ^Using examples/net1/config.json^

 ;;;
column175: 13/Feb/19 5:37 PM;nekia;We need to add 'orderers' entry to [network-configs -> network-1 -> channels -> mychannel -> orderers]. Otherwise grpcs://localhost:7050 seems to be used as default. Now that orderer and peers are discovered as expect, explorer is working with fabric 1.4 within docker environment too.;;;
column176: 13/Feb/19 10:42 PM;nfrunza;[~nekia] Would this require code change?;;;
column178: 14/Feb/19 12:24 AM;nfrunza;[~nrohith] please review gerrit commit;;;
column181:
18/Feb/19 2:43 PM;nekia;Resolved.

[https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/29349]

The default value of *asLocalhost* which is one of the parameters for channel.initailize() has changed to *true* since fabric-client 1.4.0.
 * https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-node/commit/65a8da992bed9fa151f2039bdd309dcdf9c6322e

If set *true*, the hostname mapping to localhost should be enabled ( It means that peer1.org1.example.com:7051 is automatically mapped to localhost:8051).

When using explorer within docker, the mapping will be disabled by defining *DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST=false* in docker-compose.yaml.;;;
column182: 20/Feb/19 12:26 AM;nfrunza;[~nfrunza] to pull and verify the commit.;;;

column1: Profiling endpoint is automatically exposed on /debug/pprof
column32:
problem link: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/main/orderer/common/server/main.go#L16

/debug/pprof can perform performance analysis and optimization of the program during the development of golang, and it can get execution information such as cpu, heap, block, traces, etc. during the running of the program. By adding the following code "net/http", _ "net/http/pprof" in the code, the sample data can be obtained in the form of web. Access through http:/ip:port/debug/pprof, if it includes sub-paths, block, mutex, goroutines, heap, threadcreate, you can get the corresponding detailed profile information.

But, if this debug entry is not removed afterwards, the pprof service will be exposed to the network. Through IPv4 scanning, select some reasonable ports, such as port 6060, 8080, 80, 443, you can get the debugging information and other important infos of the project.

For example, the following vulnerabilities of the same type:

CWE-200：The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

link: [https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/200.html]

CVE-2019-11248：The debugging endpoint /debug/pprof is exposed over the unauthenticated Kubelet healthz port. The go pprof endpoint is exposed over the Kubelet's healthz port. This debugging endpoint can potentially leak sensitive information such as internal Kubelet memory addresses and configuration, or for limited denial of service. 

link: [https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-11248]

column1: CONFIG transactions not synced/displayed correctly
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column171:
18/Jan/21 6:02 PM;sigma67;Some additional info from #fabric RocketChat, it seems this is a Fabric issue: 

"There was a JIRA around this. Strictly speaking, config transactions do not require transaction IDs, but much tooling automatically generates them. The real issue is that the transaction id should have never been embedded into the transaction. It's derivable from the transaction contents (in fact, from the header contents), so encoding it in the transaction was a mistake.

But this is not the real issue. Config transactions are special, in that the thing the client submits is a delta (technically, a 'config update transaction'), which is preprocessed by the orderers into a new channel config, embedded into the blockchain as a 'config transaction'. Because the contents are generated by the orderer as a new transaction, the txid of the config transaction is unknown to the client, hence, naively waiting for the txid that the client generated (for the config update txn) to commit will not work.

You can find the config update tx embedded into the config tx generated by the orderer. This is used by the other orderers and peers to ensure that the orderer processed the update correctly.
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-15411
These are Jason Yellick's words, not mine, just to attribute them to the source";;;
column172:
18/Jan/21 6:04 PM;sigma67;I have implemented a fix on our fork of blockchain-explorer, if you want to take a look. Essentially we compute our own transaction ID to serve as a reference for the API & frontend:

https://github.com/sigma67/hypersec/commit/45fbbfa4a0811159e0c9e2b7af5518923a236bb7

Here's another commit with code to sync the CONFIG rwsets, works fine for us:

https://github.com/sigma67/hypersec/commit/87d388bbfedc642c1f72447bd2effae8fc684bd3;;;

Otherwise, Explorer will count all peers which have different port with same IP address (except 127.0.0.1, localhost) as a single peer.
 This address mapping between localhost:port and each url happens inside fabric-sdk-node.
 [https://hyperledger.github.io/fabric-sdk-node/release-2.2/tutorial-discovery-fabric-network.html]

column1: API endpoints are vulnerable to SQL injection
column32:
API endpoints are vulnerable to standard SQL injection type attacks: https://owasp.org/www-community/attacks/SQL_Injection . Since I only saw a closed issue from Feb. 2019 on this topic, I created this issue.

A script to reproduce is attached (given that the Explorer URL and an authenticated token are substituted for the one in the script). The script demonstrates the vulnerability for the txList endpoint used by the Transactions view:

txList/%27%3B%20drop%20table%20users%3B%20--/0/0

After executing this, queries on the user table will fail ("relation 'users' does not exist"). It's likely that all other endpoints with query parameters are affected as well, since no string escaping is performed in the source code. For example, I tested for peersStatus with this string

peersStatus/%27%3B%20drop%20table%20users%3B%20--

This issue can result in information disclosure, but also destruction by means of "drop table users" statements (as in the provided script). Any user is able to destroy the Hyperledger Explorer installation by means of a manipulated request.

Remediation includes for example using Prepared Statements or sanitizing the string before sending them to the database server. Since the project is using node-postgres, I would recommend rewriting all queries to parameterized queries, to allow the dependency to perform proper query sanitization (see https://node-postgres.com/features/queries).

Please set this issue to confidential if needed, I found no way to do so in the "Create Issue" UI.

column1: Support Mutual TLS
column32:
HLExplorer support for mutual TLS

Ref: https://fabric-sdk-node.github.io/tutorial-mutual-tls.html

disabled: TLS is disabled
serverauth: server authentication, TLS
*{color:#FF8B00}clientauth: client authentication, mutual TLS{color}*

Steps: 

1) Use balance transfer network from fabric-samples, see https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-samples/tree/release/balance-transfer
2) Bring balance transfer network up, see https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-samples/tree/release/balance-transfer#option-2
3) Configure HLExplorer to connect to balanse transfer sample
4) Submit some transactions using sample provided  in https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-samples/tree/release/balance-transfer#invoke-request, you would have to update the Bearer token in purple font color.
Hint: you can get the token when you run the ./testAPIs.sh located in  fabric-samples/balance-transfer

 -H "authorization: Bearer {color:#403294}eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9.eyJleHAiOjE0OTQ4NjU1OTEsInVzZXJuYW1lIjoiSmltIiwib3JnTmFtZSI6Im9yZzEiLCJpYXQiOjE0OTQ4NjE5OTF9.yWaJhFDuTvMQRaZIqg20Is5t-JJ_1BP58yrNLOKxtNI{color}" \

5) Verify that blocks are appearing in Explorer
6) Let's stop the balance transfer sample and update to use the options
An orderer has TLS client authentication enabled if the ORDERER_GENERAL_TLS_CLIENTAUTHREQUIRED environment variable is set to true.
A peer has TLS client authentication enabled if the CORE_PEER_TLS_CLIENTAUTHREQUIRED environment variable is set to true.
7) Start balance transfer the same way https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-samples/tree/release/balance-transfer#option-2
8) Submit some transaction, see #4.
9) Stop, and Start Explorer , monitor if any errors, while connecting
10) Need to figure out, where to get the .pem file to supply in the explorer code to connect to balance transfer network.
    -- Do we need to generate one for the explorer client? ask in https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/fabric-ca . chat, or https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/fabric-sdk-node


A short explanation of MutualTLS, https://blog.cloudboost.io/implementing-mutual-ssl-authentication-fc20ab2392b3


*{color:#DE350B}*Issues:

One client certificate could be used for multiple users ? ( Distribute the client certificate to multiple user)
If i want to let every user to use unique client certificate, I have to generate a client certificate for every user *
{color}*

column180:
29/Mar/19 12:20 AM;mnobilio;Details for fabric-ca-client to generate client certs:
   
{code:java}
cd /home/mn/git/fabric-network/fabric-samples/bin

mn@mn-pc:~/git/fabric-network/fabric-samples/bin$ ./fabric-ca-client

Hyperledger Fabric Certificate Authority Client

Usage:
   fabric-ca-client [command]
Available Commands:
   affiliation   Manage affiliations
   certificate   Manage certificates
   enroll        Enroll an identity
   gencrl        Generate a CRL
   gencsr        Generate a CSR
   getcainfo     Get CA certificate chain and Idemix public key
   identity      Manage identities
   reenroll      Reenroll an identity
   register      Register an identity
   revoke        Revoke an identity
   version       Prints Fabric CA Client version

[snip]
{code}
 

The fabric-ca-client docs/man pages are incorrect, the list of hosts for --csr.hosts  is comma-delimited, not space-delimited.   Working on fabric-ca-client params:
   
{code:java}
./fabric-ca-client enroll  --csr.hosts peer0.org1.example.com,peer1.org1.example.com,peer0.org2.example.com,peer1.org2.example.com  --enrollment.profile tls  --enrollment.type x509  --tls.client.keyfile ZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZ  -u https://admin:adminpw@ca.org1.example.com:7054
{code}
 

 ;;;
column181: 29/Mar/19 12:45 AM;nfrunza;(y);;;
column182:
30/Mar/19 12:45 AM;mnobilio;h1. *OpenSSL certificate creation details:*

 Note the "OU"  — organizational unit — specified during cert creation should be specified as "client" and also the Fabric organization specified in the YAML file, such as "org1", should also be specified as an OU cert attribute.

The below OpenSSL one-liner creates the private key, the cert, specifies the appropriate OU as "client", and also adds the IP SAN (Subject Alternative Name) to the cert:

 
{code:java}
openssl req -x509 -newkey rsa:4096 -sha256 -days 3650 -nodes -keyout ca.key -out ca.crt -extensions san -config <(echo "[req]"; echo distinguished_name=req; echo "[san]"; echo subjectAltName=DNS:localhost,DNS:mn-pc,IP:127.0.0.1) -subj "/C=US/ST=New Jersey/L=Jersey City/O=HL Explorer/OU=client/OU=org1/CN=localhost"{code}
 

IP SAN details from the certificate created above:

 
{code:java}
X509v3 extensions:
    X509v3 Subject Alternative Name:
        DNS:localhost, DNS:mn-pc, IP Address:127.0.0.1 
{code}
 
h1. *Fabric CA enroll and register details:*

 
{code:java}
cd /home/mn/git/fabric-network/fabric-samples/bin


./fabric-ca-client enroll -u "http://admin:adminpw@ca.org1.example.com:7054" --tls.certfiles "/home/mn/git/fabric-network/fabric-samples/balance-transfer/artifacts/channel/crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/ca/ca.org1.example.com-cert.pem"
  
./fabric-ca-client enroll -u "http://admin:adminpw@ca.org2.example.com:8054" --tls.certfiles "/home/mn/git/fabric-network/fabric-samples/balance-transfer/artifacts/channel/crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org2.example.com/ca/ca.org2.example.com-cert.pem"
  
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
./fabric-ca-client register -u "http://admin:adminpw@ca.org1.example.com:7054"  --id.name "clientUser" --id.secret "clientPass"  --id.type "client"  --id.affiliation "ca.org1.example.com"
  
./fabric-ca-client register -u "http://admin:adminpw@ca.org2.example.com:8054"  --id.name "clientUser" --id.secret "clientPass"  --id.type "client"  --id.affiliation "ca.org2.example.com"
  
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  
./fabric-ca-client enroll -u "http://clientUser:clientPass@ca.org1.example.com:7054"  --csr.hosts peer0.org1.example.com,peer1.org1.example.com,peer0.org2.example.com,peer1.org2.example.com --enrollment.profile tls  --enrollment.type x509  --tls.client.keyfile "/home/mn/git/fabric-network/fabric-samples/balance-transfer/artifacts/channel/crypto-config/client/ca.key"
  
./fabric-ca-client enroll -u "http://clientUser:clientPass@ca.org2.example.com:8054"  --csr.hosts peer0.org1.example.com,peer1.org1.example.com,peer0.org2.example.com,peer1.org2.example.com --enrollment.profile tls  --enrollment.type x509  --tls.client.keyfile "/home/mn/git/fabric-network/fabric-samples/balance-transfer/artifacts/channel/crypto-config/client/ca.key"
{code}
 

 

 

 ;;;

column185:
12/Apr/19 3:29 PM;nekia;We need to specify key and cert for the client side, that is the explorer as below when calling API.
{code:java}
      - CORE_PEER_TLS_CLIENTAUTHREQUIRED=true
      - CORE_PEER_TLS_CLIENTCERT_FILE=/.../peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/User1@org1.example.com/tls/client.crt
      - CORE_PEER_TLS_CLIENTROOTCAS_FILES=/.../peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/User1@org1.example.com/tls/ca.crt
      - CORE_PEER_TLS_CLIENTKEY_FILE=/.../peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/User1@org1.example.com/tls/client.key
{code}
[The comment on core.yaml|https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/release-1.4/sampleconfig/core.yaml#L224]

I've done some check on first-network environment if mutual TLS is working properly. (This environment is a little bit tricky because we seem to need to specify the client side information for both cli container(the actual caller, through the environment variables) and each peer (through the command line arguments(--clientauth, --certfile, --keyfile)).
[~mnobilio][~nfrunza]
;;;
column186:
12/Apr/19 10:28 PM;nfrunza;[~nekia] i'm confused with these options, CORE_PEER_TLS_CLIENTCERT_FILE=/.../peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/User1@org1.example.com/tls/client.crt
      - CORE_PEER_TLS_CLIENTROOTCAS_FILES=/.../peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/User1@org1.example.com/tls/ca.crt
      - CORE_PEER_TLS_CLIENTKEY_FILE=/.../peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/User1@org1.example.com/tls/client.key

assuming that a fabric network is running, and a client needs to connect, having to setup these options would require to stop the fabric, make changes to the fabric YAML config, and then restart, what if there are many clients to connect to fabric, which is a real case, this YAML config would become a huge file.

In my understanding is that we need to generate key and cert for the client side, and register, enroll using fabric-ca admin, if the fabric is not configured with fabric-ca server another question becomes, lets keep discussion open, appreciated for looking into this

 ;;;
column187:
24/Apr/19 4:25 AM;mnobilio;Successfully enrolled a user with the Fabric CA specifying CLI params only, +*no YAML file changes are running at this point*+.   Using the pem file already sitting on the docker container.   Running the Hyperledger balance-transfer network to perform the CA user enrollment.
 * *url* ---> Specify the URL as HTTPS.

 * *tls.certfiles* ---> This is needed to call the HTTPS URL specified via the url parameter.

h2. *+fabric-ca-client  getcainfo+ - No errors making a getcainfo request:*
{code:java}
docker exec -it ca.org1.example.com bash
root@379100018d0a:/#
root@379100018d0a:/# cd /usr/local/bin
root@379100018d0a:/usr/local/bin# ./fabric-ca-client getcainfo --url https://ca.org1.example.com:7054 --tls.certfiles /etc/hyperledger/fabric-ca-server-config/ca.org1.example.com-cert.pem
2019/04/23 17:44:20 [INFO] Configuration file location: /etc/hyperledger/fabric-ca-server/fabric-ca-client-config.yaml
2019/04/23 17:44:20 [INFO] TLS Enabled
2019/04/23 17:44:20 [INFO] Stored root CA certificate at /etc/hyperledger/fabric-ca-server/msp/cacerts/ca-org1-example-com-7054.pem
2019/04/23 17:44:20 [INFO] Stored Issuer public key at /etc/hyperledger/fabric-ca-server/msp/IssuerPublicKey
2019/04/23 17:44:20 [INFO] Stored Issuer revocation public key at /etc/hyperledger/fabric-ca-server/msp/IssuerRevocationPublicKey
{code}
h2.  
h2. *+fabric-ca-client  enroll+ - No errors enrolling admin user with the CA (this step is required):*
{code:java}
docker exec -it ca.org1.example.com bash
root@379100018d0a:/#
root@379100018d0a:/# cd /usr/local/bin
root@379100018d0a:/usr/local/bin# ./fabric-ca-client enroll -u https://admin:adminpw@ca.org1.example.com:7054 --tls.certfiles /etc/hyperledger/fabric-ca-server-config/ca.org1.example.com-cert.pem
2019/04/23 18:43:22 [INFO] TLS Enabled
2019/04/23 18:43:22 [INFO] generating key: &{A:ecdsa S:256}
2019/04/23 18:43:22 [INFO] encoded CSR
2019/04/23 18:43:22 [INFO] Stored client certificate at /etc/hyperledger/fabric-ca-server/msp/signcerts/cert.pem
2019/04/23 18:43:22 [INFO] Stored root CA certificate at /etc/hyperledger/fabric-ca-server/msp/cacerts/ca-org1-example-com-7054.pem
2019/04/23 18:43:22 [INFO] Stored Issuer public key at /etc/hyperledger/fabric-ca-server/msp/IssuerPublicKey
2019/04/23 18:43:22 [INFO] Stored Issuer revocation public key at /etc/hyperledger/fabric-ca-server/msp/IssuerRevocationPublicKey
root@379100018d0a:/usr/local/bin# 
{code}
h2.  
h2. *+fabric-ca-client  register+ - No errors registering user clientOne with CA:*
{code:java}
docker exec -it ca.org1.example.com bash
root@379100018d0a:/#
root@379100018d0a:/# cd /usr/local/bin
root@379100018d0a:/usr/local/bin#
root@379100018d0a:/usr/local/bin# ./fabric-ca-client register --id.name clientOne --id.secret clientOnePass --id.affiliation org1.department1 -u https://ca.org1.example.com:7054 --tls.certfiles /etc/hyperledger/fabric-ca-server-config/ca.org1.example.com-cert.pem
2019/04/23 18:51:32 [INFO] Configuration file location: /etc/hyperledger/fabric-ca-server/fabric-ca-client-config.yaml
2019/04/23 18:51:32 [INFO] TLS Enabled
2019/04/23 18:51:33 [INFO] TLS Enabled
Password: clientOnePass
root@379100018d0a:/usr/local/bin#
{code}
 

See CA docker log attached to this ticket, which was captured during execution of the above *register* and *enroll* commands: register-user-successful-docker-log-ca.org1.example.com.log

 *[^register-user-successful-docker-log-ca.org1.example.com.log]*

column189: 26/Apr/19 11:01 PM;mnobilio;The error message is from an older enrollment run, the use was successfully enrolled, please delete comment.;;;
column190:
26/Apr/19 11:06 PM;nekia;Ultimately, we don't need any changes on explorer because setTlsClientCertAndKey is automatically called in [fabric gateway connect call|https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-node/blob/18865fad628e96d5d0b89a2478e4f3035e97330b/fabric-network/lib/gateway.js#L217].

All we have to do is adding the configuration for mutual TLS to balance-transfer environment.

By applying [^BE-568.patch] to fabric-samples environment, you can see that explorer is working under the environment which is enabled mutual TLS.

The important configuration is adding not only msp/tlscacerts but also ca cert which is referred by fabric-ca (org*.example.com/ca/ca.org*.example.com-cert.pem) to TLS_CLIENTROOTCAS_FILES.
 * You can use the identity provided by fabric-ca for mutual TLS

[~mnobilio] [~nfrunza];;;
column194: 14/Nov/19 6:23 AM;nfrunza;Per Atsushi comment, https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-568?focusedCommentId=59526&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-59526 , we do not need to support TLS, closing jira.;;;

column1: Security vulnerability
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column171:
18/Apr/19 11:27 AM;nekia;npm - Security advisories [https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/803]

Version 4.4.2 or later of tar seems to be installed automatically by node-pre-gyp ( Please see below in detail. {"tar": "^4"} includes ver 4.4.2 or later ).

[https://github.com/mapbox/node-pre-gyp/blob/master/package.json#L32]

This issue has not been resolved yet.

[https://github.com/facebook/create-react-app/issues/6790];;;
column172:
18/Apr/19 11:29 AM;nekia;The workaround (installing node-pre-gyp) suggested in the issue does not work for my environment.

[https://github.com/facebook/create-react-app/issues/6790#issuecomment-482275680]

 

The workaround (editting package-lock.json and using npm clean install) suggested in the issue  works on my environment. But it's still doubtful that is the good practice.

[https://github.com/facebook/create-react-app/issues/6790#issuecomment-482549458]

 ;;;
column173:
26/Apr/19 1:16 PM;nekia;By updating react-scripts from 2.1.8 to 3.0.0, all security vulnerabilities are fixed.
{noformat}
cd client
npm install --save  react-scripts@3.0.0
{noformat}
But, when building client app, we have a problem:
{noformat}
> hyperledger-explorer-client@0.3.9 build /home/vagrant/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/client
> react-scripts build


There might be a problem with the project dependency tree.
It is likely not a bug in Create React App, but something you need to fix locally.

The react-scripts package provided by Create React App requires a dependency:

  "eslint": "^5.16.0"

Don't try to install it manually: your package manager does it automatically.
However, a different version of eslint was detected higher up in the tree:

  /home/vagrant/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/node_modules/eslint (version: 5.12.0) 

Manually installing incompatible versions is known to cause hard-to-debug issues.

If you would prefer to ignore this check, add SKIP_PREFLIGHT_CHECK=true to an .env file in your project.
That will permanently disable this message but you might encounter other issues.

{noformat}
This is a version conflict problem between version dependencies brought by the different packages seperately.
 This problem occurs not only on "eslint" package, but also on other eslint related packages ( like "babel-eslint" ).
 It's same with the situation reported in the following open issue on react-script repo.
 [https://github.com/facebook/create-react-app/issues/5247#issuecomment-432197864]

Could you please ask someone who is the react expert to look over this problem? [~nfrunza]

 ;;;
column174: 03/May/19 5:50 AM;nfrunza;moving to the next sprint, seeking more info on how to fix it.;;;

[https://github.com/facebook/create-react-app/releases/tag/v3.0.0]

And I've resolved the problem with the project dependency tree by upgrading eslint and babel-eslint packages for backend to align with react-app. We need a code-review by react experts, I think.

[~nfrunza];;;

column1: Integrate Fabric ca-server into the fabric network
column32:
This is needed in order to implement admin functionality of provisioning Users

1) Use sample fabric-ca provided by HLFabric to:

    a) register HLExplorer admin

    b) register users

2) TBD, create docker image for fabric-ca?

3) Configure fabric-ca server with postgreSQL DB

4) Create CRUD REST API for user profile

 

As discussed on 06/04, in order to authorize various participants in network we need to connect to CA service. Currently fabric server component does not have ca service in the first network setup.

column175:
27/Feb/19 10:42 PM;nekia;[~nfrunza] As you can see in [getRegisteredUser()|https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/min-config-rel-4.0/app/platform/fabric/FabricClient.js#L267] and [_enrollCaIdentigy()|https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/min-config-rel-4.0/app/platform/fabric/gateway/FabricGateway.js#L199], we need to have the following input fields to register and enroll a new user.
* admin username/password
* For registering : [RegisterRequest|https://fabric-sdk-node.github.io/global.html#RegisterRequest__anchor] for a new user
** enrollmentID
** enrollmentSecret (Optional)
** role (Optional)
** affiliation
** maxEnrollments
** attrs 
* For enrolling : [enroll()|https://fabric-sdk-node.github.io/FabricCAClient.html#enroll__anchor]
** enrollmentID
** enrollmentSecret
** csr
** profile
** attr_reqs;;;

column172:
19/Mar/19 10:36 PM;nfrunza;Raju, and I did some testing to see the output that fabric operations service returns, so far looks good.
The implementation we are targeting is to get the metric directly from the fabric operation service, and optional to provide additional instructions on how to configure prometheus, and maybe grafana.
The reason we want to go by simple solution ("to get the metric directly from the fabric operation service") is because the configuration of prometheus and grafana may introduce more complexity in installing and running explorer.
We will attempt to create instructions on how to configure with prometheus and grafana, but this is a low priority, and it may require addition time.;;;

column1: Limit number of rows in transaction and block list queries in backend API
column32:
1) Limit the number of rows in queries of CRUDService methods, by applying filter, date range and organization
 getTxList(channelName, blockNum, txid)
 getBlockAndTxList(channelName, blockNum)

 

Link to the rocket chat

[https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=d5BEFdBmeJkDmmeBA]

Pass to the REST API

 – date range (db field createdt )[FROM , TO], timestamp, applies to both blocks and transactions

 - organization, values (All, org1, org1, etc), , support multi selection, All not to be a part of multis election
 * 
 ** When all is selected SQL should ignore peer, and organization filter

 * 
 ** default FROM, and TO should be one day

Rows limit should not be added, the solution for rows limit should be discussed 

 

 

SQL pseudocode

if(organization === 'All')

{   no organization should be in WHERE clause  }

else

{   WHERE organization in (val1, val2, etc)  }

column1: Retrieve block details from database
column32:
Retrieve block details from DB, and not from store, use block hash, similar to transaction details:

SQL: (or use A LEFT [OUTER] JOIN ) instead of a subquery 
 select blocks.blocknum,blocks.txcount ,blocks.datahash ,blocks.blockhash ,blocks.prehash,blocks.createdt, (select name as channelname from channel where
 channel_genesis_hash ='eee49424fc28addc13cb2866190bd52bd6a16543dc096a5a8f33a766b31f2fed' ) from blocks 
 where 
 blocks.blockhash = 'eee49424fc28addc13cb2866190bd52bd6a16543dc096a5a8f33a766b31f2fed'
  and blocks.channel_genesis_hash ='eee49424fc28addc13cb2866190bd52bd6a16543dc096a5a8f33a766b31f2fed'

 

Code change will have changes for:

UI, REST API

 

Add SWAGGER definition for the REST API :
*1) app.get('/api/blockActivity/:channel_genesis_hash', function(req, res)*
*2) rename misspelled method name:* 
{color:#de350b}*getBlockAcitvityList*{color}(channel_genesis_hash) 
To: *getBlockActivityList*

column1: Resolve licensing issues discovered by Fossology scan
column32:
Explorer source was scanned using Fossology to determine license for files contained in the following repositories
 * http://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/blockchain-explorer

From the Hyperledger Charter ([https://www.hyperledger.org/about/charter)] Section 13, all files that are included in Hyperledger projects should either be licensed with the Apache License, Version 2.0 for source code or Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License for documentation.  There are a few files in the Explorer source base that do not meet these requirements.  See the attached file for results. 

The files listed under Attribution and No License Found need to be resolved. For the Attribution tab, these files should be replaced with code meeting the Apache 2.0 license.

For the files listed as No License Found, we should first check with the original contributors to make sure that they can contain an Apache 2.0 license (for source code) or a Creative Commons with Attribution 4.0 license (for documentation). Once this has been verified, the editable files must be annotated with the correct license text and/or the SPDX short identifiers (see  [https://spdx.org/sites/cpstandard/files/pages/files/using_spdx_license_list_short_identifiers.pdf]).
For binary files, a license.txt file should be included in the directory calling out the file types and the associated license.

Any files that are not covered by Apache 2.0 or CC by 4.0 that need to remain with the project will need to go through an exception process with the governing board.
column171:
31/Oct/17 4:19 AM;tkuhrt;[~robert.feng] : Added the latest scan of the code from October 12th. Can we re-open this issue? 

Here are some things that stood out in this scan:
 * The file at explorer_client/js/index-gen.js contains a GPLv3 component called Packery. This component will likely need to be removed.
 * There are some very large binary files checked into the repo (at fabric-docker-compose-svt/release). Should these be part of the source repo, or should these be removed?;;;

column1: [java-chaincode] In Chaincode-to-Chaincode invocation, main transaction become successful even if second chaincode invocation fails.
column32:
Lets take a reference to example chaincodes: LinkExample and MapExample.

In LinkExample, we are invoking MapExample chaincode and in put function of MapExample chaincode we are doing some check on number of arguments i.e if the number of arguments is odd then we are throwing an RuntimeException. 

Now, when we invoke LinkExample chaincode with odd number of arguments and it internally invokes MapExample chaincode with same number of arguments then MapExample chaincode throw an RuntimeException and shim layer catch this exception which results in the failure of invoke transaction to MapExample. But the whole transaction (invoke transaction to LinkExample) is getting successful even if when part of the transaction fails. 

In this senario, MapExample is not sending any message regarding its failure to LinkExample which results in success of transaction to LinkExample.

column1: Hyperledger Fabric 1.3 - Expired Admin Certificates Rotation
column32:
Currently, we have a Fabric 1.3 network consisting of 3 orderers, 2 peers, and the KAFKA setup. In our expired Fabric 1.3 network, we want to replace the admin certificates. Because the current channel configuration retains the old admin identities of peers and orderers, we are unable to perform network administration tasks such as chaincode upgrade and channel upgrade.

We tried updating channel configurations using an expired orderer admin certificate (which is currently stored in configuration), but it gave an error that the certificate was expired. We tried various environment variables such as,
ORDERER_GENERAL_AUTHENTICATION_NOEXPIRATIONCHECKS=true 
so that we could bypass the expiration check at least once, but since we are on the 1.3 network and not using RAFT consensus, it doesn't seem to work.

Has anyone else had this problem or known how to fix it?

Is there a way to run blockchain orderer and peers run in non-root users

Env Details : We are using the hyper ledger fabric 2.2 Version

column1: Opettavien värityssivujen edut lapsille - Varityskuvat
column32:
Värityssivut Varityskuvat ovat loistava tapa käsitellä tylsyyttä ja muuta. Tiesitkö, että värjäävä lapsi stimuloi mielikuvitusta ja samalla rentoutuu? Väritys toimii hyvin samalla tavalla aikuisilla, mutta lapsilla on suurin vaikutus. Opi värityksen tärkeimmät edut sivuilla [Värityskuvat Lapsille|https://varityskuvat.com/] ja katso itse, kuinka tärkeää on tarjota hauskaa tässä muodossa.
h2. Värityksen edut

*Varityskuvat* eivät ole vain hauskoja, vaan myös tapa lopettaa tylsyys. Ensinnäkin se on motoristen taitojen oppimista ja parantamista eli liikuntaelinten käsittelykyvyn parantamista. Värityssivut stimuloivat mielikuvitusta, joten meidän ei pitäisi odottaa lasten aina värittävän kuvion osoittamalla tavalla. Mustat hiukset Elsalla? Miksi ei! Sininen koira? Loistava.

Väritystä käyttämällä pienemmät lapset oppivat väripaletista, ja vanhemmat lapset saavat loistavan johdannon kirjoittamisen oppimiseen. On syytä lisätä, että värjäyksellä on positiivinen vaikutus hermostoon, mikä auttaa lapsia selviytymään tunteista. Tulostettavat värityssivut ovat loistava vaihtoehto kirjan muotoisille värityssivuille helpon saatavuuden ja laajan valikoiman ansiosta.

Tapa lopettaa tylsyys ja viettää aikaa perheen kanssa. Huolimatta syistä, joiden vuoksi valitsemme värityssivut useimmin, kannattaa väritys tehdä osaksi kotirutiinia. Matkapuhelinten ja televisioiden aikakaudella se on erittäin tärkeää. Silmät lepäävät, vauva keskittyy ja lepää samaan aikaan.
h2. Värityssivut suosikkisatujesi hahmoilla

Ne stimuloivat taiteellisia aisteja ja piristävät sinua. Joskus ne ovat jumalan lahja, kun haluamme pitää lapsen kiireisenä jollain luovalla, ja joskus ne ovat hyvä tekosyy viettää aikaa yhdessä. Tulostettavat värityssivut Varityskuvassa voidaan ladata ilmaiseksi tältä sivulta. Mikä tärkeintä - meillä on erittäin mielenkiintoisia ehdotuksia, jotka tukevat kehitystä.

Rakkaat, rohkeat koiramme Paw Patrolilta ja Ponit Ponyilta, jotka oppivat taikakoulussa ystävyyden. Sieltä löytyy Peppa Pig, jota Frozenin nuorin ja sankarit ihailevat. Voin kertoa rehellisesti, että värityssivut kuuluisan kissa Pusheenin kanssa olivat minulle suuri yllätys. Tämä on yksi tyttäreni suosikkikissoista. Värityssivut Pusheenin Varityskuvat.
h2. Kuvioiden edut ja paljon muuta

Värityssivuilla on vielä enemmän etuja. Myös yllämainitun sivuston tulostettavat värityssivut tarjoavat tyypillisesti opetusratkaisuja. Voimme tulostaa värityssivuja, jotka opettavat lapset kirjoittamaan kirjaimia ja numeroita. Jotkut kuviot tukevat kehon motorisia taitoja ja ovat erinomaista harjoittelua. Mallit opettavat myös kärsivällisyyttä ja toimintaa tiettyjen mallien mukaan.

Kärsivällisyys on erittäin tärkeä ominaisuus, josta on hyötyä elämässä. Värityssivut ovat hyvä tekosyy tukea lapsia tässä asiassa. Muista, että jokainen lapsi kasvaa omaan tahtiinsa, joten on normaalia, että he menevät rajan yli tai pitelevät värikynää epävarmasti. Se vaatii myös harjoittelua, joten anna lasten tehdä tällaisia ​​esteettisiä virheitä.

Miksi värityssivujen tarjoaminen lapsille kannattaa? Yhteenveto

*Muista, että lasten värittämisen tärkeimmät edut ovat:*
 * Mielikuvituksen elvyttäminen. Lapsi yhdistää värejä ja tarkistaa, miten ne sulautuvat toisiinsa.
Looginen ajattelu. Toisin kuin näyttää, värityssivut opettavat loogista ajattelua. Oikeiden värien valinta, samanlaisten löytäminen ei ole vain mielikuvituksen, vaan myös logiikan asia.
 * Tehokkaat motoriset taidot. Fyysinen kunto, refleksit. Näitä taitoja lapsi harjoittelee värittäessään.
 * Kärsivällisyyden oppiminen. Ajan myötä lapsesi oppii, että hitaat liikkeet ovat enemmän aikaa vieviä, mutta tehokkaampia.
 * Väritys antaa tyytyväisyyden tunteen ja saa lapset kehumaan töitään.

Tietoa maailmasta. Pieni taiteilija tutustuu ja löytää maailmaa erilaisten värityssivujen kautta.
Kannustamme kaikkia vanhempia tukemaan lastensa kehitystä värityskirjojen avulla. Lapset rakastavat tätä leikkimuotoa. Kun näemme, että pieni taiteilija ei ole kiinnostunut, kannattaa tarjota hänelle värityssivuja hänen suosikkiaiheestaan.

column1: HL Explorer accessibility design
column32:
Based on raised question, see https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/HYP/2019+Q2+Hyperledger+Explorer?focusedCommentId=13861739#comment-13861739

Guidelines: https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG21/

Some articles about: 

https://uxdesign.cc/designing-for-accessibility-is-not-that-hard-c04cc4779d94

What can be added to HL Explorer accessibility?
- Currently HLExplorer can change a dark theme
- Design usable focus states (partially implemented)

To consider:

- Font size increase 
- Add enough color contrast
- Design usable focus states ()
- Use labels or instructions with form fields and inputs
- Write useful alternative text for your images and other non-text content
- Use correct markup on your content
- Support keyboard navigation


TODO:
Get an Accessibility Audit. Use an audit service to find out if your product works with assistive technologies and meets WCAG 2.0 level AA. Use the audit results to fix problems and do another test.

connection.json is not copied by setting up for external builders
column32:

After install command `{{peer lifecycle chaincode install}}` run, `{{connection.json}}` is supposed to be installed in `{{/var/hyperledger/production/externalbuilder/builds/\{{.CC_PACKAGE_ID}}/release/chaincode/server/connection.json}}`
There is `{{connection.json}}`, but this file is 0 byte.

I tried to check different version as well.
```
2.2.0 -> OK
2.2.1 -> OK 
2.2.2 -> OK 
2.2.3 -> Failed
 2.2.4 -> OK
 2.3.0 -> OK
 2.3.1 -> OK
 2.3.2 -> Failed

column1: Log rotation problem of "app.log"
column32:
Environment:
Hyperledger Explorer v1.1.6 
docker version 20.10.6

I used Blockchain Exploler to discover the BC network created by Hyperledger Fabric "fabcar" sample. "app/platform/ fabric/config.json" is defined as follows.

-----
{
 "network-configs": {
 "test-network": {
 "name": "Test Network",
 "profile": "./connection-profile/test-network.json"
 },
 "test-network2": {
 "name": "Test Network",
 "profile": "./connection-profile/test-network2.json"
 }
 },
 "license": "Apache-2.0"
}
-----

"./connection-profile/test-network.json" contains the connection profile of org1.peer0, and "./connection-profile/test-network2.json" contains the connection profile of org2.peer0. As a result, the following three processes run. (1 main.js and 2 sync.js)

-----
ubuntu 16134 1.0 4.3 1971116 86232 pts/2 Sl 02:08 0:04 node dist/main.js name - hyperledger-explorer
ubuntu 16149 1.0 3.6 1954108 73108 pts/2 Sl 02:08 0:04 /usr/local/bin/node /home/ubuntu/blockchain-explorer/dist/sync.js test-network Test Network 1
ubuntu 16156 1.0 3.6 1954344 73508 pts/2 Sl 02:08 0:04 /usr/local/bin/node /home/ubuntu/blockchain-explorer/dist/sync.js test-network2 Test Network 1
-----

In Explorer, log rotation is done once a day by setting of log4js. When the date changes and log rotation occurs, the following three "app.log" files ("app.log.20210701.[1-3]") are created. There should be only one log file after log rotation. In addition, they don't include the log output by "main.js". Looking at lsof, each process has accessed different log files.

-----
app.log <- Accessed by process #16134(main.js)
app.log.20210701.1　<- Accessed by process #16156(sync.js)
app.log.20210701.2　<- Accessed by process #16149(sync.js)
app.log.20210701.3
-----

The following description is in the log4js specification (https://log4js-node.github.io/log4js-node/clustering.html):
"If you’re running log4js in an application that uses node’s core cluster then log4js will transparently handle making sure the processes don’t try to log at the same time." Previous log rotation problems may have been caused by multiple processes (main.js and sync.js) have accessed to the same log file (app.log). They also says that tcp appender should be used to prevent it.

column1: security vulnerabilities

h5. https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/security/dependabot/package-lock.json/jsrsasign/open
h5.  Dependabot cannot update jsrsasign to a non-vulnerable version

The latest possible version that can be installed is {{8.0.24}} because of the following conflicting dependencies:
  {{fabric-ca-client@2.2.5 requires jsrsasign@^8.0.20
 fabric-ca-client@2.2.5 requires jsrsasign@^8.0.20 via fabric-common@2.2.5
 fabric-network@2.2.5 requires jsrsasign@^8.0.20 via fabric-common@2.2.5}}
 The earliest fixed version is {{10.2.0}}.

column1: queryInstantiatedChaincodes method fails when setting explorer with non-admin fabric client access credentials
column32:
With reference to below Jira we can see the implementation approach taken for this method 
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-750
 
From Fabric end we have two different system chaincodes to handle the 1.x(install-instantiate model) and 2.x(lifecycle)model
 
*lscc*: manages the chaincode lifecycle for the 1.x releases of Fabric.
*_lifecycle*: implements the Fabric chaincode lifecycle process
 
For Explorer connected to Fabric with 1.x channel application capability "lscc" chaincode is contacted and "GetChaincodes" inside it retrieves all the *instantiated* chaincodes
 
whereas 
For Explorer connected to Fabric with 2.x channel application capability "_lifecycle" chaincode is contacted and "QueryInstalledChaincodes" inside fails from fabric end itself to fetch the list of installed chaincodes
 
Can we update this method to display list of committed  chaincodes on the network, instead of fetching installed chaincodes

25/Jun/21 12:04 AM;nekia;Thank you for sharing the debugging result. I agree with you. We'll use QueryChaincodeDefinitions instead of QueryInstalledChaincodes, for lifecycle model. It will make non-admin allowed to access chaincode info.

column1: Fail to deploy explorer to an organization which a new peer has been added
column32:
{quote}when I add **peer** from another organization in my network and join it to channel, it **doesn't have** installed **_lifecycle** chaincode (1) and that's the reason why **explorer**, deployed for this organization is **failed**.
I found a workaround for it - to approve some chaincode, it could be even not being packed and installed, like
`{{peer lifecycle chaincode approveformyorg --name randomchaincodename --package-id 1 --tls --tlsRootCertFiles \{path_here} --cafile \{path_here} --version 1 --channelID defaultchannel --sequence 1}}`. I executed it from initial peer of first organization. Somehow it forced new peer to install _livecycle chaincode (2) and than explorer could start.
{quote}
Please refer the following for detail:
 * [https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=B9YbGMMatsXkWsoBy]

column1: Explorer process cannot be stopped by using "stop.sh"
column32:
I started Hyperledger Explorer using docker image, and executed "stop.sh" on the root directory from outside of the container to stop Explorer process once.
{quote} docker exec -d [explorer_container_id] /bin/sh /opt/explorer/stop.sh
{quote}
However, the following result was obtained and failed to stop Explorer process.
{quote}Stopping node process hyperledger-explorer, id root
sh: invalid number 'root'
{quote}
I checked "stop.sh", and detected it uses "ps" command to identify the process ID of Explorer.
{quote}ps aux | grep -v "awk" | awk '/name - hyperledger-explorer/ \{print $2}'
{quote}
But Alpine Linux, which is used by Explorer container, returns the following values for "ps" command.
{quote}PID   USER   TIME    COMMAND
45     root     0:12    node app/main.js name - hyperledger-explorer
{quote}
So correct process ID cannot be obtained by the above method. (Misidentify "root" as process ID.) 
I suppose that it will work correctly by specifing the format of the output of "ps" command like follows.
{quote}ps -eo pid,args | grep -v "awk" | awk '/name - hyperledger-explorer/ \{print $1}'
{quote}

column1: Besu in the DMZ as a relay
column32: Is it possible to run Besu inside a secure DMZ?  i.e. act as a relay in the DMZ for the ethereum mainet and/or other private networks to allow P2P networking to take place from the outside world to the inside world.  It should be able to configure rules as well so that we can block unknown/malformed message types over 30303.  Being in a secure DMZ means that there is no DNS and no storage. i.e. Rather than running as a node with storage it should simply act as a relay, sort of like a proxy for port 30303.

column1: Add new pane for peer metrics to dashboard
column32:
Fabric peer has built-in prometheus exporter (disabled by default). When network administrator enables this feature on each peer, blockchain explorer (automatically or based on configuration) detects it and showing on the dashboard. 

 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 
https://hgf20.sched.com/event/a3XE/after-production-prepare-the-software-factory-for-blockchain-maintenance-marco-alarcon-jaime-pradenas-bolsa-de-santiago?iframe=no&w=100%&sidebar=yes&bg=no
 !screenshot-2.png|thumbnail! 
 !screenshot-3.png|thumbnail! 
 !screenshot-4.png|thumbnail! 
https://hgf20.sched.com/event/Y402/monitoring-and-securing-your-blockchain-5-basics-everyone-should-know-aaron-klein-blocwatch?iframe=no&w=100%&sidebar=yes&bg=no

We have already had prometheus/grafana container services configuration in ./docker-compose.yaml. We can preset each configuration for prometheus and grafana to scrape metrics from each peer enabled metrics feature and visualizing them on grafana dashboard. Grafana also provides a feature to share each panel on a dashboard via shared URI. We can retrieve this URI by using HTTP API and embedded them on our dashboard within iframe component.

[https://play.grafana.org/d/000000012/grafana-play-home?orgId=1&from=1593263670556&to=1593267270558&viewPanel=4]

  
This comparison among tools is quite useful for us to pick up what kind of new feature we should do next
 https://www.blocwatch.com/features

column1: User authorization, workflow, credential persistence
column32:
Need to identify user types:

1) Admin: HLExplorer application would act as a client, can be considered an admin user type, as it needs to pull all the data from the fabric network

2) Users that are part of the MSP (membership services provider )
 * 'Org0.admin': any administrator of the Org0 MSP
 * 'Org1.member': any member of the Org1 MSP
 * 'Org1.client': any client of the Org1 MSP
 * 'Org1.peer': any peer of the Org1 MSP

3) Data is separated on channel level
 * A Hyperledger Fabric channel is a private “subnet” of communication between two or more specific network members, for the purpose of
 conducting private and confidential transactions. 
 4) How is data filtered by user types and viewed in HLExplorer
 5) Private data

Logging to to HLExplorer application

I came across this message: [https://lists.hyperledger.org/g/fabric/message/4643?p=,,,20,0,0,0::relevance,,user,20,2,0,26203197]

Excerpt from it:

Remember that in the Blockchain word, people stop using

{username, password, third party}

now, before your credential is hold by a company, whenever you lost your password, you can claim it back by clicking on your forgot password and answer or proof some security question to proof you are the owner of the resource.

*In the Blockchain world ussername and password are replace by Asymmetric Cryptography, a Key Pair of

{Private key , Public Key}

, public key is use as your identity, in the case of cryptocurrency the user address is derive from the public key, and the private key is used to proof who you are, and you are the owner of that private key, you have 100% responsible for you key, to back up or to store in security and not to lost it, and ask for somebody to help you.*

This is the reason behind the Blockchain evolution, "Great power comes great responsibility", but if you don't want that power, you can turn back to the old fashion, store your private key in a third party company such as wallet company, so when your private key is lost or has been compromised, you can ask them to recover it back, if they have that functionality. Some company store that private key for you, but some others still keep the original spirit and don't keep it for you, they only keep your record transaction and public key.

In case you want to create a Blockchain system by yourself, and want to help user recover their private key, you need to have a Key Management functionality:
 1. What to do when user forget the key, lost the key, or the key has been taken by someone else?
 Multi factor authentication, Security identity proof, Recovery process is depend on you, everyone is dealing with it differently.

column1: Use React Hooks and stop using recompose package which is not maintained any more
column32:
https://github.com/acdlite/recompose#a-note-from-the-author-acdlite-oct-25-2018

{quote}Hi! I created Recompose about three years ago. About a year after that, I joined the React team. Today, we announced a proposal for Hooks. Hooks solves all the problems I attempted to address with Recompose three years ago, and more on top of that. I will be discontinuing active maintenance of this package (excluding perhaps bugfixes or patches for compatibility with future React releases), and recommending that people use Hooks instead. Your existing code with Recompose will still work, just don't expect any new features. Thank you so, so much to @wuct and @istarkov for their heroic work maintaining Recompose over the last few years.{quote}

column1: Single Line PEM in certificateAuthorities connection profile
column32:
As per the current logic, single line pem in "certificateAuthorities" tlsCACert in connection profile is not supported. This configuration will trigger error saying that "path" is required. But this configuration is supported in "peers" configuration.
{code:java}
"certificateAuthorities": {        
"ca.org1.example.com": { 
"url": "https://localhost:7054",            
"caName": "ca_org1",

column1: Can't use mutual tls
column32:
In current [master version|https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/commit/c85c86fe8fa77b5bed4cb8b2e88ac74658f84d9b], I can't use mutual tls option. 

Because, [setTlsClientCertAndKey in FabricGateway.getDiscoveryResult|https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/c85c86fe8fa77b5bed4cb8b2e88ac74658f84d9b/app/platform/fabric/gateway/FabricGateway.ts#L377] dose not set tls informatoin.
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Transaction creator_id_bytes not being synced
column32:
The transactions arriving in SyncService through the SDK's block subscription have a signature header. For me, this signature header contains a field *id_bytes *indicating the certificate.

However, this field is currently addressed by txObj.payload.header.signature_header.creator.*IdBytes *(SyncService.ts l. 534). That results in the table field being empty. 
I did some research and it seems this was changed in Fabric SDK recently (June):  FABN-1544
File in question: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-node/blob/master/fabric-common/lib/Identity.js
Link to commit: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-node/commit/d22e1a1b02b79bdbdc25b11de454cbe379fb1e27#diff-88ec303f1f83e7e9d9810f1dfd493c941a05ac741a21e3330528df9488d356b6

Since this field contains the identity of the transaction sender, I would consider this an important feature to be supported. 

I'm using the latest fabric samples test-network with Fabric 2.2.

 * Update version of supported fabric if need it [here|https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/client/src/FabricVersion.js#L3] (I don't think we need it this time)
 * Push all above updates into master
 * Add `v1.1.2` tag to the latest commit on master branch via Github web UI

column1: Transaction timestamps are incorrectly stored in database
column32:
{color:#444444}As of the latest master, the timestamp of the first transaction in the block is assigned to {color}{color:#444444}*{color}*all*{color:#444444}*{color}{color:#444444} transactions in that block (see SyncService.js). In l.486 the block timestamp is defined as the timestamp of the first tx in the block, and thereafter this variable is reused for {color}{color:#444444}*{color}*every tx*{color:#444444}*{color}{color:#444444} in the for loop starting in l. 503. It is finally committed to the database in l.631. However, each transaction actually has a unique timestamp that differs based on when it was created. See the following example for block 177 in my test blockchain, which was created by adding some logging output to SyncService.js after modifying it to include the correct timestamps. Previously the timestamps would all be equal to the first (and thus equal to the block timestamp, which is also based on the first tx).{color}
{code:java}
177
2020-09-15T12:22:28.863Z
2020-09-15T12:22:28.935Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.000Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.069Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.631Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.708Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.796Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.873Z
2020-09-15T12:22:29.948Z
2020-09-15T12:22:30.023Z
{code}

I submitted a PR here: https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/pull/177

column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column171:
19/Aug/20 10:53 PM;nekia;You're right. These multiple definitions of network name are obviously not good.

That's to detect duplicate user registration on each network by using sequelize attribute.

[https://sequelize.org/master/class/lib/model.js~Model.html#static-method-init]

[https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/model/User.js#L11]

e.g. We don't allow to register the same user ID within the same network, but we allow to do that across the different networks.

 

But we might not need to do that kind of tricky thing any more if using the following approach.

[https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42195348/how-to-define-unique-index-on-multiple-columns-in-sequelize/46070340];;;

I am having issues with the latest hyperledger explorer (1.1.0) on my setup (hlf peer 1.4.6).

My log is full of "Unable to decodeEndorserTransaction" / "TypeError: rangeQueryInfoProto.raw_reads is not iterable" messages.

Any hints what could cause this?

column1: Organizations option in profile that allows a single organization
column32:
In the current process, only one organization applies to the first one in the array.([https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/platform/fabric/gateway/FabricGateway.js#L83])

However, getOrgnaizationConfig in FabricConfig.js returns key, cert path from the last organization.([https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/platform/fabric/FabricConfig.js#L174])

It seems that the logic needs to be changed.
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column171:
26/Apr/20 11:39 AM;nekia;Thanks [~Specia1]

That's right. That's a problem when specifying multiple organization in a connection profile.;;;
column172:
15/May/20 5:49 PM;Specia1;Will multiple organizations be made available in one profile?
If not, I think I need to convert the json from an array to a single object.;;;
column174:
17/May/20 9:47 AM;Specia1;[~nekia] 
 Should the issue of whether to support multiple organizations be made a new issue?

And it seems that we need to solve this issue.

So I think we only need to make use of the information for the first organization. 

Can I take care of it?;;;
column176:
20/May/20 5:45 PM;Specia1;I agree your comment.

So, I changed and pull according to your request.

 

Please check below PR.
 [https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/pull/106]

 

Thank you.;;;

column1: HLExplorer, support Hyperledger Fabric v2.0
column32:
Test if HLExplorer supports Hyperledger Fabric v2.0

Steps would be:

- install one of the fabric samples in HL Fabric v2.0.0-beta, https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-samples/tree/v2.0.0-beta
- connect hle explorer to the fabric sample network 
- use latest sdk for node v1.4.4
- test connections, verify dashboard, and all the tabs for fulfillment of the data from the network
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column171:
08/Jan/20 2:30 AM;nfrunza;On macOS i had to install go version go1.13.5 darwin/amd64
 Problem starting the network, seems that the fix was to remove the GOROOT, and GOPATH from the .bash_profile, my path looks like:
 echo $PATH
/opt/local/bin:/opt/local/sbin:/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/bin:/Users/USER_ID/.nvm/versions/node/v8.15.0/bin:/Users/USER_ID/workspace/fabric-2.0.0-beta/fabric-samples/bin:/Users/USER_ID/workspace/STATIC-CODE-ANALYZER/pmd-bin-6.14.0/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin
;;;
column172:
06/Apr/20 6:53 PM;jeevasang;Upgraded all softwares and downloaded fabric 2.0 images
 curl -sSL [https://bit.ly/2ysbOFE] | bash -s – 2.0.1 1.4.6 0.4.18
  
 Integrated fabric-network@2.0 in Hyperledger explorer with fabric-network@1.4.8 - All data's are displaying only chain code is not displayed.
  
 npm package didn't upgrade for fabric-network 2.0 and they have latest version  fabric-network 1.4.8
 They have fabric-network@2.0.0-beta.4 version ([https://www.npmjs.com/package/fabric-network/v/2.0.0-beta.4])

@[~vchinoy] please let me know do we need to use beta version or can we wait for release stable version of fabric-network@2.0.0;;;
column173: 25/Apr/20 12:49 AM;vchinoy;Maintainers have decided to wait to for Node SDK for Fabric 2.0 t complete this task. Currently Explroer supports fab versoin 1.4.8;;;

column175:
11/May/20 3:04 PM;nekia;As jeeva has already reported, even after official release of node sdk for fabric v2.*, we would not be able to make use of it for query of information on the network as we used to do before.
I think we have the following 3 options
* Query the network via peer command line
  ** We might only need to write some scripts to run peer command for local or remote fabric network
  ** But it would be a little bit tricky
* Query the network via LSCC of fabric
  ** We need to implement some logic to get access to Ledger System ChainCode, based on the logic which fabric-sdk-node for v1.4 has 
    *** https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/core/scc/lscc/lscc.go
    *** https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-node/blob/release-1.4/fabric-client/lib/Channel.js
* Query the network via protobuf (fabric-protos)
  ** As fabric-sdk-node for v2.x has done, using protobuf as interface between app and network;;;
column176: 29/May/20 3:54 PM;nekia;I've created a new feature ticket for this topic. We'll keep discussion on the new JIRA and close this JIRA;;;

column1: Allow only "admin" to manage user of their own organization
column32:
* "admin" means as follow
 ** User specified with [client.adminCredential|https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/864b622a7b7782c540fa68ef63f85bec63d50cd0/app/platform/fabric/connection-profile/first-network.json#L11] in each connection profile
 ** User registered with 'admin' role by using user register API (/api/register)
 * The "admin" user can manage (create/list/remove user) only for users in the organization the admin belongs.

At the moment, the GUI interface for registering user on Explorer will be showing even if you login with non admin user, but actual operations (e.g. registering a new user) should be refused.

column1: Reduce explorer container image size
column32:
With the following changes to Dockerfile, reduce container image size from 942MB (compressed size on docker hub : 425MB) to less than 200MB.
 * Use Multi-Stage Docker Builds
 To avoid including unnecessary dependencies in the image
 * Add some entries to .dockerignore
 * Install only packages for production
 * Prune unnecessary files by using node-prune tool
 * Delete some large files manually

column1: Fabric v2.0.0 support
column32:
We'll do adding of this support with keeping the compatibility to fabric v1.4.x. When completing this JIRA, explorer will be able to support both fabric v1.4 and v2.1 ultimately.

Basically we need to do some works for handling the following specification change of fabric-sdk-node.
https://hyperledger.github.io/fabric-sdk-node/master/tutorial-migration.html

* Replace fabric-client to fabric-network and our query implementation
Because of removal of fabric-client package for fabric v2.1, administrative functions are obsoleted from sdk. So we need to do it ourselves. Basically we can do that by invoking function of each system chaincode (cscc, qscc, lscc) directly. To do this, we need to understand about not only Explorer, but also fabric and fabric-protos.
* Migrate wallet related implementation
There are some changes on Wallet class interface
* Event listeners
In fabric-sdk-node v2.1, event listener is redesigned. Explorer is using block listener to monitor new block commit

As an optional work item, it had better if we can do some code clean up around our implementation using service discovery.
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

But some functionalities seem to be obsoleted in SDK v2.0 such as querying channels. We need to do some work around for these changes.;;;

column1: In chaincode view, tx count of each chaincode is always counted 0, when using new chaincode lifecycle
column32:
When updating txcount of chaincode in explorer, explorer figures out which records should be updated by channel name and chaincode name included in each transaction. Currently chaincode name on chaincodes table is including not only name but also version and ID. So explorer can't find any records to be updated when receiving transactions.
 !image-2020-06-21-17-22-35-043.png|thumbnail!
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)

column1: Can't query chaincode from network when enabling CA in network profile
column32:
When enabling CA server in network profile, admin certificate is retrieved from CA server instead of using the certificate specified in the network profile. But the certificate retrieved from CA server does not have admin priviledge so explorer running under the certificate fails to query chaincode on the network. Because the query to the installed chaincode is required admin policy by default. Our CA server support has been incomplete yet, so we'll disable this functionality temporarily.

 
{noformat}

27/Jun/20 11:44 PM;nekia;To enable metrics feature on each peer in byfn sample, please refer below.
{code:java}
diff --git a/first-network/base/peer-base.yaml b/first-network/base/peer-base.yaml
index 11dc8a7..c8b33ca 100644
--- a/first-network/base/peer-base.yaml
+++ b/first-network/base/peer-base.yaml
@@ -25,6 +25,8 @@ services:
       - CORE_PEER_TLS_ROOTCERT_FILE=/etc/hyperledger/fabric/tls/ca.crt
       # Allow more time for chaincode container to build on install.
       - CORE_CHAINCODE_EXECUTETIMEOUT=300s
+      - CORE_OPERATIONS_LISTENADDRESS=0.0.0.0:9443
+      - CORE_METRICS_PROVIDER=prometheus
     working_dir: /opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer
     command: peer node start

@@ -45,6 +47,8 @@ services:
       - ORDERER_GENERAL_CLUSTER_CLIENTCERTIFICATE=/var/hyperledger/orderer/tls/server.crt
       - ORDERER_GENERAL_CLUSTER_CLIENTPRIVATEKEY=/var/hyperledger/orderer/tls/server.key
       - ORDERER_GENERAL_CLUSTER_ROOTCAS=[/var/hyperledger/orderer/tls/ca.crt]
+      - ORDERER_OPERATIONS_LISTENADDRESS=0.0.0.0:8443
+      - ORDERER_METRICS_PROVIDER=prometheus
     working_dir: /opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric
     command: orderer
{code}
Then start container service of Prometheus and Grafana
{noformat}
docker-compose up -d proms grafana
{noformat}
And access [http://localhost:3000|http://localhost:3000/];;;

column1: Implement queryInstantiatedChaincodes by using "getchaincodes" func on LSCC (for legacy chaincode lifecycle)
column32:
* Call "getchaincodes" func of "lscc" contract on default peer with no argument 
 ** [https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/a282f7132565d509d3ba6d502cd9c07cc5e567f0/core/scc/lscc/lscc.go#L92]
 * Decode the response data as fabprotos.protos.ChaincodeQueryResponse as below
 ** [https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-node/blob/master/fabric-protos/bundle.json#L3074] 
 ** [https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/e60a7a46b999e4af1d39798fa618a4efdc2b9d0b/app/platform/fabric/gateway/FabricGateway.js#L263]
 * 1 reference of queryInstantiatedChaincodes ( SyncService::insertNewChannelChaincode ) redirects to our new implementation.
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column171:
06/Jun/20 7:04 PM;nekia;For fabric v2.1, we need to use another system chaincode. You need to query to both system chaincode and manage these result by merging into one object. [~jeevasang]
h2. For fabric v1.4 ( for legacy chaincode lifecycle)

system chaincode: 'lscc'

method name: 'getchaincodes'

arguments: -

data type of response: fabprotos.protos.ChannelQueryResponse
h2. For fabric v2.1 ( for new chaincode lifecycle)

system chaincode: '_lifecycle'

method name: 'QueryInstalledChaincodes'

arguments: '' (empty string)

data type of response: fabprotos.lifecycle.QueryInstalledChaincodesResult

 ;;;
