column1: Blockchain-explorer synchronization error when connected to amazon managed blockchain network
column32:
I'm trying to connect hyperledger explorer to amazon managed blockchain network. I'm using ```./examples``` template in blockchain-explorer to do this soo. I modified the connection profile given in examples directory according to the amazon blockchain network and mounted necessary tls certificates to the container(```docker-compose.yaml``` file in the root of ```blockchain-explorer```. Everythin is fine and it is connecting to the defined peer without causing any error. some how, When I open web interface(localhost:8080), all it is showing is 0 blocks, 0 transactions, 0 chaincodes.. I've attached screenshots to this thread. please have a look at it.

So I've checked logs of explorer.mynetwork.com and it is showing ``` [INSERT ERROR] - value too long for type character varying(64)```

Please have a look at screenshot and let us know.

!Screenshot (55).png!

!Screenshot (57).png!

Thanks,

Salman.
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column171:
16/May/20 8:45 PM;nekia;[~Salmandabbakuti]

Can you share the following information on your environment?
 * Peer ID / Address (ex. peer0.org1.example.com:7051)

If the peer ID is too long, it might be a problem because explorer records the information in DB as a varchar(64).

 
{code:java}
$ docker exec explorerdb.mynetwork.com sudo -u postgres psql -x fabricexplorer -c 'table peer'
-[ RECORD 1 ]--------+-----------------------------------------------------------------
id                   | 1
org                  |
channel_genesis_hash | b400b25677e4577402a0194bfdda8f6ce89959b16fe7824665f45f4a62571069
mspid                | Org1MSP                           <= varchar(64)
requests             | peer0.org1.example.com:7051       <= varchar(64)
events               |                                   <= varchar(64)
server_hostname      | peer0.org1.example.com            <= varchar(64)
createdt             |
peer_type            | PEER
network_name         | first-network
-[ RECORD 2 ]--------+-----------------------------------------------------------------
id                   | 2
org                  |

{code}
 

 ;;;
column172: 16/May/20 8:54 PM;Salmandabbakuti;[~nekia], Thanks for your response, I'm able to fix that out by modifying [[https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/persistence/fabric/postgreSQL/db/explorerpg.sql|https://github.com/DevOpsInternational/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/persistence/fabric/postgreSQL/db/explorerpg.sql]]. all rows length to the higher value(256). and built a custom image and used it in my project. it is common that peers' names in amazon managed blockchain network will be long alphanumeric strings. so, rows length should be set high to make explorer to compatible for Amazon managed blockchain.;;;
column173: 17/May/20 12:20 AM;nekia;Thanks [~Salmandabbakuti] for sharing your solution. If you will create a new pull request, that would be also great. If not, that would be fine, too. We'll handle it. :);;;
column174: 17/May/20 1:29 AM;Salmandabbakuti;[~nekia] Added a pull request. [|https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/pull/105];;;

column1: Reimplement e2e test framework with using ginkgo
column32:
Currently Explorer are using Behave (BDD test framework in python) which was used as a defacto in fabric before. But fabric-test repo, the Behave has already been obsoleted and switched to Ginkgo+Gomega (BDD test framework in Golang). To align with this direction and simplify test suite in Explorer, we need to take time and effort to switch e2e test framework to Ginkgo based.

[https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-test]

Add {{turuslan}} and {{pobepto}} as maintainers for {{iroha-integration}} branch.

 

Currently code for Fabric and Iroha is not compatible.

Code from these repositories will be in PR:

 - [iroha-explorer-backend|https://github.com/turuslan/iroha-explorer-backend]

column1: Suggestion, and feedback, new improvements
column32:
I would like to propose some changes, including some that I have already done in my environment and have worked well. I made simple changes, but they helped me every day, especially in the environment where I work, which is Docker. Others are more complex and I think it is worth an evaluation and planning.
 * config.json and explorerconfig.json

 # I propose to change config.json to config.js in order to use environment variables in the settings. This makes life so much easier that you work with Docker. The same for the explorerconfig.json file ( change to explorerconfig.js). *[ Implemented ]*

 * Improvements (I would like to propose several changes regarding the code itself, logic and rules. But of course, it will be hard work and a help would be very welcome!). Already implemented some improvements, others are still in the development phase and also in the planning phase.

 # Reconnect() event in sync.js. Replaces calls to the shutDown event to reconnect when an 'unhandledRejection' or 'uncaughtException' occurs, this helps if the Peer is DOWN. The Explorer sync keeps trying to reconnect until it succeeds, so in this case until the Peer gets UP again. *[ Implemented ]*
 # One config file per network (Nik Fruza suggestion too). *{color:#0747a6}[ Planning ]{color}*
 # Do not make any more necessary +config.js+ settings, such as: Organizations, Peers and Orderers. In this case Explorer would grab everything from the network, just connect to the channel and start using discovery for this function. I've already started to implement, and it has worked, but I think we need to evaluate the best way. *{color:#ff8b00}[ In development / planning ]{color}*
 # In the file: app/platform/fabric/utils/FabricUtils.js, change the validation conditions of 'privateKeyPath' and 'signedCertPath'. I added a fs.readdirSunc() because if it was a file it returned an exception on the system. *[ Implemented ]*
 # Upgrade NodeJs version to 10. *[ Implemented ]*
-- I have a jira for upgrading to Node 10, when SDK for Node will be ready too.

Update bash, path to fabric samples

source  ~/.bash_profile

./byfn.sh -m restart

configure HLExplorer to  fabric-sample/first-network/

column1: Explorer app service stops response after lost connection to explorer-db
column32:
I've tried to use explorer (its docker images), but faced with the connection problem after some time its normal activity. I've figured out that the problem is the following: explorer doesn't reconnect to db (postgreSQL) on losing connection.

It seems that piece of code for db reconnection is not good enough. 

Here [https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/persistence/postgreSQL/PgService.js#L70]

 

*PROTOCOL_CONNECTION_LOST* is something from mysql world, not from postgresql.

 

To reproduce it just stop explorer-db docker container (stop db) for a while and wait for connection error in the explorer container, start explorer-db again.

column1: node 4.x is explicitly allowed, but only needs a single line to be supported
column32:
One file appears to be using es6 features that are only available in strict mode in node 4.x, once the single `'use strict';` statement is added, `npm test` passes.

The overly restrictive engine-strict statements also need removing (and note that npm 2.x works fine, I'm not sure why it was thought that the SDK had a dependency on a particular npm version).

https://gist.github.com/sam-github/66f9345fa1c892789e44901412aead67
column171: 27/Apr/18 8:23 PM;satheeshk;Please check if this is relevant, as we are upgrading to Node 8.x;;;

column1: Transaction Count is showing wrongly for Individual Chaincodes -- Chaincode Tab
column32:
Fabric- v1.4.3 

RAFT Orderer Set up.

Two application chaincode installed - ldbc and marble

Clicking on Chaincode Tab --> Count of transactions are showing wrong values against each individual chaincodes.

As in the attached screenshot — shown as 14 transaction total.

 

From the transaction tab i got to know --- total 11 transactions has been carried out and 3 are config updates

Out of the 11 transactions --
System chaincde – *lscc* ---> 9
Application chaincode — *ldbc* --> 2
Application Chaincode --- *marble* --> 0

 

!Chaincode_Tab.PNG!
column33:
Fabric - v1.4.3

Raft Orderer Set up - 5 Orderers

3 Orgs :-
 # Orderer Org 
 # Org1 - 2 Peers
 # OrgA - 1 Peer

column1: Alignment - Project Incubation Exit Criteria
column32:
From: https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/HYP/Project+Incubation+Exit+Criteria

Sufficient test coverage
The project must include a comprehensive unit and integration test suite and document its coverage. Additional performance and scale test capability is desirable.

Sufficient user documentation
The project must including enough documentation for anyone to test or deploy any of the modules.

Alignment

Requirements fulfillment
The project must document what requirements and use cases it addresses.

Architecture
The project must document how it fits within the Hyperledger Architecture

Compatibility with other Hyperledger projects
Where applicable, the project should be compatible with other active projects.

Release numbering: the project should use the Hyperledger standard release taxonomy, once that is agreed upon.

Project must make a release, even a “developer preview”, before graduation.

column1: Getting the Hyper Ledger security badge
column32:
See how to graduate from incubation: 

https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/HYP/Project+Lifecycle?src=contextnavpagetreemode



Ref: https://events.linuxfoundation.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/cii-bp-badge-2019-03.pdf


From the email:

Passing criteria, approval for the HLExplorer project Badge CII
Inbox


Nick Frunza <nfrunza@gmail.com>
Wed, Jun 19, 3:50 PM (1 day ago)
to helpdesk

Hello,

We are working now on graduating HLExplorer project from the incubation, we have created Badge CII form, and working on required items, see at: https://bestpractices.coreinfrastructure.org/en/projects/2710

Once we are at the 100% of the Badge CII, who will pre-scan, pre-approve, and approve once we met the CII criteria?

thank you


Nick Frunza
Jun 19, 2019, 3:56 PM (1 day ago)
-- Nik Frunza

Ry Jones
Wed, Jun 19, 4:16 PM (1 day ago)
to community-architects, me

+CA


Silona Bonewald
7:23 PM (16 minutes ago)
to Ry, me, Community

So the next step is making sure they have all the Project lifecycle requirements done like Vendor Diversity so they will be prepared before the go the TSC for a vote.

https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/HYP/Project+Incubation+Exit+Criteria

and https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/HYP/Project+Lifecycle

Thank you!
Silona

column1: ReadMe HL, Explorer documentation bug - Requirements
column32:
Identified by AMex team members *Requirements*

It’s better to share related commands to validate the version of all the prerequisite tools.

Provide reference for installation for the prerequisite tools. (URL etc.)

Since its common for users to have Node 7+ locally (I was having it), it’s better to share some handy commands to update it to lower version, for example for Mac we could add something like this:

_brew install node@6_

_brew unlink node_

_brew link node@6_

column1: Showing the Individual Block Size
column32:
Showing the individual block size of the blockchain.

This would be beneficial in case of setting up the configuration in gossip state protocol of peer to peer. Due to Grpc max size of 100 MB the parameters can be configured accordingly of how many blocks to be fetched at once from the bootstrap peers.

column1: Verify HLExplorer with the latest Fabric v1.4.2
column32:
1) Start hl fabric first network with the lates Fabric v1.4.2
2) Update hl explorer connection profile to the Fabric v1.4.2
3) Perform a smoke test with





Excerpt from announcement email 

The Hyperledger Fabric maintainers are pleased to announce the availability of Fabric v1.4.2!

v1.4.2 delivers the next set of patches and fixes on the Fabric 1.4 long-term support (LTS) release.

v1.4.2 also delivers Kafka to Raft migration capability for the ordering service. The Raft-based ordering service is simpler to operate since it requires no dependencies external to the orderer nodes. It also enables the ordering service to be provided by different organizations across different data centers. For these reasons we expect Raft to become the preferred ordering service choice for production Fabric networks.

Please see the release notes for additional improvements and suggestions:
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/releases/tag/v1.4.2

Download instructions:
https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.4/install.html

And for more information on Raft, see the What's New documentation and Raft documentation:
https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.4/whatsnew.html#raft-ordering-service
https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.4/orderer/ordering_service.html#raft


Thank you,

The Hyperledger Fabric maintainers

column172:
24/Jul/19 1:35 PM;nekia;[FABN-864] As an application developer using the fabric-network API, I want to utilize 'service discovery' to discover endorsing peers - Hyperledger JIRA

[FABN-1256] 'discovery-as-localhost' config setting should be false - Hyperledger Jira

Since v1.4.1 release, fabric-sdk-node has owned the default value of 'discovery-as-localhost'. So we don't need our own logic to toggle this flag anymore.

And the default value has been changed to false since fabric-node-sdk v1.4.2 maintenance release. As a result of these changes, 'localhost mapping'(discovery-as-localhost) is always disabled if not overriding the option somehow. 

I've added an explicit export statement of 'DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST' environment variable to ./start.sh script.;;;
column173:
24/Jul/19 10:04 PM;nfrunza;Thank you Atsushi, great catch, if you recall we have the syncstart.sh process too, let me know if you can add the DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST  on the constructor call of the blockchain-explorer/app/platform/fabric/FabricClient.js, we would need to export DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST from the node backend, or add similar in the syncstart.sh
https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer#110-run-hyperledger-explorer---- , see
From new terminal (if Sync Process in Standalone).

cd blockchain-explorer/

./syncstart.sh (it will have the sync node up).

If the Hyperledger Explorer was used previously in your browser be sure to clear the cache before relaunching.

column1: Ignoring style code for coverage purposes
column32:
[https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/blockchain-explorer-verify-x86_64/246/Code_20Coverage_20Report/]

 

In explorer UI, they have a structure called HOC to wrap core component with material-UI. Because of this structure, we found it hard to get coverage reached over 80%.

I think this code block is related to only CSS, not logic of GUI. We might not need to cover this code block in our unit tests.

I put a comment statement for istanbul to ignore this code block in coverage purpose. Now we can reach over 80% coverage in all aspects.

column1: Continue on e2e test, Sprint 35
column32:
This jira is created based on Atsushi comments in https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-618:

See comments in: https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-618?focusedCommentId=60088&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-60088

Excerpt from https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-618 comments:

I think we are ok since we have already had e2e test suite for REST API and it's invocable via npm command (or a shell script).

We might need to satisfy the following criteria later on:

Adding another e2e test suite to increase coverage for GUI
It is SUGGESTED that the test suite cover most (or ideally all) the code branches, input fields, and functionality.

Adding a trigger to the Jenkins script, to run our e2e test every time some changes are committed
It is SUGGESTED that the project implement continuous integration (where new or changed code is frequently integrated into a central code repository and automated tests are run on the result).

column1: Security vulnerability in 'diff' npm
column32:
1 diff vulnerability found in …/test/package-lock.json 14 hours ago
Remediation
Upgrade diff to version 3.5.0 or later. For example:

"dependencies": {
  "diff": ">=3.5.0"
}
or…
"devDependencies": {
  "diff": ">=3.5.0"
}
Always verify the validity and compatibility of suggestions with your codebase.

Details
WS-2018-0590 More information
high severity
Vulnerable versions: < 3.5.0
Patched version: 3.5.0
A vulnerability was found in diff before v3.5.0, the affected versions of this package are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attacks.

column1: Hyperledger Project Release+Taxonomy
column32:
Follow up on HLFabric https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/HYP/Release+Taxonomy

Releases at the Hyperledger Project are done according to the semver.org taxonomy.1)  In addition to the semantic versioning scheme, where we use MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH numbering, following the established guidance given in the semver specification, it is also strongly encouraged that projects should use the following tags, as permitted by semver:

preview

alpha

beta

rcN (release candidate N - where N is 1-n incremented for each candidate)

snapshot-<sha> for interim, possible unstable builds 2)

preview
Not feature complete, but most functionality is implemented. Any missing functionality that is committed to the production release is identified, and there are specific people working on those features. Not heavily performance tuned, but performance testing has started with the first few hotspots identified and perhaps even addressed. No “highest priority” issues are in an open state. First-level developer documentation provided to help new developers with the learning curve.

alpha
Feature complete, for all features committed to the production release. Ready for Proof of Concept-level deployments. Performance can be characterized in a predictable way, so that basic PoC's can be done within the bounds of published expectations. APIs are documented. First attempts at end-user documentation have been made. Developer documentation is further advanced. No “highest priority” issues are in an open state.

beta
Feature complete for all features committed to the production release, perhaps with optional features when safe to add. Ready for Pilot-level engagements. Performance is very well characterized and active optimizations are being done, with a target set for the Production release. No “highest priority” or “high priority” bugs are in an open state. Developer documentation is complete; end-user documentation is mostly done.

rcN
For a forthcoming production release, we will prepare multiple candidate releases intended to be heavily tested by the community. As we cycle through resolving uncovered issues, we will issue another when no remaining highest or high priority issues remain, and repeat until we feel confident in releasing a production release, with no qualifier. e.g. 1.0.

1) Note that this is not about exiting from the incubator, though a beta or production release should not be made while still in incubation.
2) Further, for interim, possibly unstable builds working towards a tagged release, we will append the first seven (7) characters of the SHA-1 hash of the latest commit for the branch from which the build is produced, so that we can identify the commit level of a given test, etc. e.g. 0.6-snapshot-36e99cd

column1: Warning flags, CII Badge
column32:
see https://bestpractices.coreinfrastructure.org/en/projects/2710/edit#quality

The project MUST enable one or more compiler warning flags, a "safe" language mode, or use a separate "linter" tool to look for code quality errors or common simple mistakes, if there is at least one FLOSS tool that can implement this criterion in the selected language. [warnings] 
Examples of compiler warning flags include gcc/clang "-Wall". Examples of a "safe" language mode include JavaScript "use strict" and perl5's "use warnings". A separate "linter" tool is simply a tool that examines the source code to look for code quality errors or common simple mistakes. These are typically enabled within the source code or build instructions.
Warnings justification

column1: Update SWAGGER with latest API
column32:
1) swagger needs to be secured with admin role, we can use defined admin user from the connection profile, ex: blockchain-explorer/app/platform/fabric/connection-profile/balance-transfer.json
  "adminUser": "admin",
 "adminPassword": "adminpw", 
2) configure swagger with latest swagger npm and  OpenAPI (https://swagger.io/docs/specification/about/)
 -- we can have modify the existing swagger.json, or add @swagger notations in REST API using 'swagger-jsdoc' npm.
3) JWT token needs to be passed to REST API , we can generate if from the API when the user enters user/password
4) Go over the https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/min-config-rel-4.0/swagger.json, and update with the latest api, and the documents, instructions per REST API.
Unused REST API, should be retired.

column1: CII badge, Automated test suite
column32:
See at: https://bestpractices.coreinfrastructure.org/en/projects/2710/edit#quality

The project MUST use at least one automated test suite that is publicly released as FLOSS (this test suite may be maintained as a separate FLOSS project). [test] 
The project MAY use multiple automated test suites (e.g., one that runs quickly, vs. another that is more thorough but requires special equipment). There are many test frameworks and test support systems available, including Selenium (web browser automation), Junit (JVM, Java), RUnit (R), testthat (R).


To be in accordance with the best practices we need to prove that we have automated test.

column171: 16/May/19 12:29 AM;nfrunza;[~nekia] Atsushi, You put down some automated test BDD e2e , just review what the best practices requirements are, and if you think we are ok, we can rate CII badge for the HL explorer. ;;;
column172:
17/May/19 9:26 AM;nekia;[~nfrunza] 
 I think we are ok since we have already had e2e test suite for REST API and it's invocable via npm command (or a shell script).

 

We might need to satisfy the following criteria later on:
 * Adding another e2e test suite to increase coverage for GUI
 ** 
{quote}It is SUGGESTED that the test suite cover most (or ideally all) the code branches, input fields, and functionality.
{quote}
 * Adding a trigger to the Jenkins script, to run our e2e test every time some changes are committed
 ** 
{quote}It is SUGGESTED that the project implement continuous integration (where new or changed code is frequently integrated into a central code repository and automated tests are run on the result).
{quote};;;

column1: CII Badge, perform Dynamic code analysis
column32:
It is SUGGESTED that at least one dynamic analysis tool be applied to any proposed major production release of the software before its release. [dynamic_analysis] 
A dynamic analysis tool examines the software by executing it with specific inputs. For example, the project MAY use a fuzzing tool (e.g., American Fuzzy Lop) or a web application scanner (e.g., OWASP ZAP or w3af). In some cases the OSS-Fuzz project may be willing to apply fuzz testing to your project. For purposes of this criterion the dynamic analysis tool needs to vary the inputs in some way to look for various kinds of problems or be an automated test suite with at least 80% branch coverage. The Wikipedia page on dynamic analysis and the OWASP page on fuzzing identify some dynamic analysis tools. The analysis tool(s) MAY be focused on looking for security vulnerabilities, but this is not required.
Dynamic analysis justification

column1: Test HLExplorer release with Composer, and Cello
column32:
Test and create a config.json sample with CELLO project.
We need to test Cello with fabric, 1.2, 1.3, and 1.4

HLExplorer compatibility
tags:
v0.3.6  - up to v.0.3.7.1 :  fabric-1.2
v0.3.8 up to v.0.3.9 : fabric-1.3
v0.3.9 fabric-1.4

Fabric -1.2
1) Install Cello that supports fabric-1.2
2) Install HLExplorer v0.3.7.1
3) Configure config.json, you may need to look at the https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/platform/fabric/config-cello.json , and use the https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/platform/fabric/config.json to match the paths, and update, as we did for composer.

Fabric -1.3
1) Install Cello that supports fabric-1.3
2) Install HLExplorer v0.3.8
3) Configure config.json, you may need to look at the https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/platform/fabric/config-cello.json , and use the https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/platform/fabric/config.json to match the paths, and update, as we did for composer, or if use same config.json you configured for fabric-1.2

Fabric -1.4
1) Install Cello that supports fabric-1.
2) Install HLExplorer v0.3.9
3) Configure config.json, you may need to look at the https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/platform/fabric/config-cello.json , and use the https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/platform/fabric/config.json to match the paths, and update, as we did for composer, or if use same config.json you configured for fabric-1.2, and fabric-1.3

column1: Add e2e sanity check test running to the verification of Jobbuilder
column32:
To detect a problem caused by new changes, add a minimum e2e test to the verification of Hyperledger Jobbuilder.

The e2e sanity check test includes the following test:
 * On first-network and balance-transfer example network
 ** POST auth/login
 ** GET api/channels
 ** GET api/channels/info
 ** GET channel_genesis_hash
 ** GET block_height
 ** GET block data
 ** GET api/peersStatus/mychannel
 ** GET block activity

It takes about 20 min to complete on the Jenkins server (It took 8 min on average before).

 !screenshot-1.png|width=840!

column1: Add task to  "precommit"
column32:
Add a task to  "precommit":  that will do verify and run all the tests before committing to gerrit, this is required as we had failures in the past that cause  jenkns build to fail

Task should do the following

npm install && cd client/ && npm install && npm run build && npm test -- -u --coverage && cd .. && cd app/test && npm install && npm run test && cd ../..

if the result fails then commit should be cancelled

column1: CII Badge, Static code analysis
column32:
see https://bestpractices.coreinfrastructure.org/en/projects/2710/edit#analysis

At least one static code analysis tool (beyond compiler warnings and "safe" language modes) MUST be applied to any proposed major production release of the software before its release, if there is at least one FLOSS tool that implements this criterion in the selected language. [static_analysis] 
A static code analysis tool examines the software code (as source code, intermediate code, or executable) without executing it with specific inputs. For purposes of this criterion, compiler warnings and "safe" language modes do not count as static code analysis tools (these typically avoid deep analysis because speed is vital). Some static analysis tools focus on detecting generic defects, others focus on finding specific kinds of defects (such as vulnerabilities), and some do a combination. Examples of such static code analysis tools include cppcheck (C, C++), clang static analyzer (C, C++), SpotBugs (Java), FindBugs (Java) (including FindSecurityBugs), PMD (Java), Brakeman (Ruby on Rails), lintr (R), goodpractice (R), Coverity Quality Analyzer, SonarQube, Codacy, and HP Enterprise Fortify Static Code Analyzer. Larger lists of tools can be found in places such as the Wikipedia list of tools for static code analysis, OWASP information on static code analysis, NIST list of source code security analyzers, and Wheeler's list of static analysis tools. The SWAMP is a no-cost platform for assessing vulnerabilities in software using a variety of tools. If there are no FLOSS static analysis tools available for the implementation language(s) used, select 'N/A'.


Review on some tools
https://www.softwaretestingmagazine.com/tools/open-source-javascript-code-analysis/

Recommended by : https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Static_Code_Analysis

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Static_Code_Analysis

column1: Code verification, must be under the Apache License
column32:
Verify all the files:

All code has been made available under the Apache License and is free of incompatible dependencies

All new files should have the following header at the beginning of the file, depending of the file type, .js, .ts, .sh, etc, comment should be applied appropriately.
If any old file has a different licensing, DO NOT remove, there were contributors and we do not want to remove their licensing.

.js file type
/**
 *    SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0
 */

.sh file type
#
#   SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0
#

column1: Show only selected keys from json based on custom selection
column32:
This will require a user to select which keys of the json he wants to display.

 

Proposal:

Provide a screen with a json structure and ability to custom select the keys to be displayed. Selection of the keys should be saved in a table config and used as a filter to reconstruct the json when returning in transaction or block details windows.

 Note that this may have a huge impact on performance, either data is hashed or we are not storing it, or store it hashed 

To get more feedback from Pau

column1: Better connection handling when connecting to fabric network
column32:
Many developers complains about failures to connect to their fabric networks, some connecting to VM's, some to AWS instances, some have miss-configuration.
Verify if the following is addressed in release-3.6, if not add support for below.

Need to address the following:   
 * connection timeout (when this occurs error needs to be added to the log as ERROR) 
 * connection denied, this could be the case when the network is using CA (Certificate of Authority), add to log as error
 * peers down, add to log as error
 * invalid certificates, this could be due to misconfiguration, add to log as error
 * invalid path, or no such files, directory, add to log as error
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column171:
25/Apr/19 12:52 AM;nfrunza;All above addressed 
connection timeout (when this occurs error needs to be added to the log as ERROR) 
 --- connection timeout is handled
connection denied, this could be the case when the network is using CA (Certificate of Authority), add to log as error
--- error is added to the logs
peers down, add to log as error
--- an error is added to the log, could be either connection denied, or timeout
invalid certificates, this could be due to misconfiguration, add to log as error
--- this is handled, no such file error, or access denied error is triggered
invalid path, or no such files, directory, add to log as error
--- error is added to the logs;;;

column1: Update explorer DDL data types to support noSQL
column32:
Hyperledger fabric uses a noSQL database levelDB, and  couchDB
To avoid possible insert, and update errors due to size of the defined column and value inserted, we need to review defined currently DDL and use a data type that could support large value.

FYI:
LevelDB stores keys and values in arbitrary byte arrays, and data is sorted by key. ... LevelDB is not an SQL database. Like other NoSQL and Dbm stores, it does not have a relational data model and it does not support SQL queries.

column1: Setup default admin profile
column32:
1) To be able to connect to HLF v1.1 we need to create a default admin profile, see [https://fabric-sdk-node.github.io/tutorial-network-config.html]

2) add default profile under "blockchain-explorer/config/adminProfile.yml

3) add instructions in README.md on how to edit this file

 

As an ADMIN i should be able to add users to a network
 * Security on the Fabric is enforced with digital signatures. All requests made to the fabric must be signed by users with appropriate enrollment certificates. For a user's enrollment certificate to be considered valid on the Fabric, it must be signed by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA). Fabric supports any standard CAs. In addition, Fabric provides a CA server

column1: Test BE-582, BE-552, and JWT invalidation
column32:
Test the following jiras:
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-552
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-582


JWT invalidation

The only time you should need to invalidate the user is if their permissions have been changed, or revoked.
Logout would usually be a user initiated action, in which case the client can simply clear/reset/delete the JWT token it currently has for the user.


Who can register, and enroll an user?

Option 1:
- ADMIN user that is the admin of the fabric-ca server
 A: admin user only can register regular user

Option 2:


Where is the user persisted?


Option 1:
-fabric-ca server
-explorer postgreSQL DB
 
A: No user data will be saved in DB


How to update the password?

column1: Add more test scenarios for e2e test
column32:
Currently, e2e test set introduced by BE-573 just covers only a few REST API calls on a simple fabric network.

In this Jira, we're going to add more REST API calls as below for first-network and balance-transfer environment:
 * networklist
 * login
 * register
 * enroll
 * Channel list
 * Channel's info
 * Peer status
 * blockactivity
 ** current stats
 ** updated stats by a newly generated tx
 
These test sets will be prepared for both first-network and balance-transfer environment.

column1: Delete deploy_explorer.sh from repo

Some people have used `deploy_explorer.sh` by mistake to bring up docker container.

https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=B9D8vKwF9vBv82wXs
https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=B9D8vKwF9vBv82wXs
https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=nRqyKjHDkNCbswsbD

 We've currently recommended using docker-compose to bring up explorer container. That's because to keep flexibility for integrating easily to other docker environments.

https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer#run-hyperledger-explorer-using-docker-compose

https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.2/private-data/private-data.html

HOWTO: https://fabric-sdk-node.github.io/tutorial-private-data.html


User reported that Explorer doesn't display the data: "*When mychannel had one chaincode(“mycc”),the explorer work fine.But after I added another chaincode(“testcc”) which uses private-data ,the explorer can’t load block or tx which generated by “testcc*”."

Excerpt from the email, printscreen attached

Thank you for your reply



OS:
CentOS Linux release 7.5.1804 (Core)

Explorer branch:
Master

Are you behind the proxy:
No

How did you configure explorer?
Follow the page

Steps you performed before staring explorer.
Follow the page

How do you start explorer
./start.sh

Thank you for reporting the issue

Is the data from "chaincode(“mycc”)" broadcasted from the fabric, please send the printscreens  of the chain-codes per channel, navigate to CHAINCODES TAB and take a printscreen.

Please run the following commands using CLI tools, and email the prinscreens:

$peer chaincode list --channelID=<channel name>  --instantiated   
(example: peer chaincode list --channelID=mychannel --instantiated)

$ peer chaincode list --channelID=<channel name> --installed     
 (example : peer chaincode list --channelID=mychannel --installed)


Nik

column1: Use operations service in Explorer
column32:
From the HL docs: https://buildmedia.readthedocs.org/media/pdf/hyperledger-fabric-ca/latest/hyperledger-fabric-ca.pdf

Tutorial on medium https://medium.com/@jushuspace/hyperledger-fabric-operations-service-tutorial-7a845257368d

1) Follow up instructions provided in jira https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-544 to configure fabric network with operations service.
    -- Instructions provided here : https://jira.hyperledger.org/secure/attachment/16975/fabric-metrics%20enablement.txt
2)Need decision on :
-- method of getting metrics from the Operations service
-- categorize metrics
-- create a list of options we want to use
-- define UI prototype
-- feed UI with metrics, either by using web-socket or REST API
-- interval of refreshing metrics from fabric operations service
-- interval of feeding metrics into UI

** To be continued

Sample configuration provided in file https://jira.hyperledger.org/secure/attachment/17006/docker-compose-base.yaml

Sample curl urls, based on docker-compose-base.yaml
    curl http://localhost:8443/metrics
    curl http://localhost:9443/metrics
    curl http://localhost:9444/metrics
    curl http://localhost:9445/metrics
    curl http://localhost:9446/metrics 

Metrics response samples, see https://jira.hyperledger.org/secure/attachment/17007/metrics.response.txt, and https://jira.hyperledger.org/secure/attachment/17008/metrics.orderer.txt

column1: Handle graceful explorer shutdown
column32:
When running balance transfer sample, and explorer is stopped by ./stop.sh it will kill the balance transfer application .
We need a mechanism to kill the node by the process id it was started, or another aproach that would not kill the other nodes, similar behavior was noticed while running explorer in docker 

Ref: could be our solution https://www.twilio.com/blog/2017/08/working-with-environment-variables-in-node-js.html

column1: Reduce .git folder size
column32:
The .git folder is 165MB whereas the entire codebase is about 3MB. The .git folder is large because it is caching some binaries uploaded in a previous commit.

This can be viewed by this command, which lists the largest objects in the codebase's git history:
The first column is the size in bytes.

{code:bash}
 $ git rev-list --all --objects | awk '{print $1}' | git cat-file --batch-check | sort -k3n | tail -20 | sed 's/\(.*\) \(.*\) \(.*\)/echo \3 \$(git rev-list --all --objects \| grep \1)/g' | sh

column1: Integrate Authentication mechanism into Blockchain explorer
column32:
Checkout passport.js and how can we utilize it in explorer.
The idea is that every organization who is part of the network should be able to use explorer to look at their ledgers. And the admin for that org should be able to provision users who can access explorer in three different roles.
ADMIN ---- has all of the query capability and can also manage channel, manage peer, manage users
QUERY ---- can view all navs that yield query only results like blocks, transactions, installed chaincodes, peers on the network
INSTALL ---- has all of the query capability and can also install and invoke chaincodes and transactions.

So we need to put in AUTH.
Explorer should be accessed via https
User should be presented with a login page
User should be authenticated against the users database which could be AD.
User should be logged out after so many minutes of inactivity
User should be able to click on Logout navigation link to initiate logout

column1: Create login page for HLExplorer - Phase 2
column32:
Create login page for explorer, fields  [Login, Password], and should be provided on login page as a legend
Default user: admin
Default password: adminpw

Requirements:

Default explorer user will be the admin that is initially setup during the start up process, or by running some script.
New users will be enrolled by the admin user, or default account for HLExplorer.
The admin login credentials should be the fabric-ca admin, or other user credentials that are defined in:  blockchain-explorer/app/platform/fabric/config_ca.json file.

We have two modes for TLS [enabled, disabled]

Call to rest api should we on initial page load, with evaluation of the response from REST API '/api/login'
 1) TLS disabled proceed to explorer dashboard page
2) TLS enabled return login page, user should enter default admin credentials


Add configuration to  file : blockchain-explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json
options:   "enableAuthentication": false|true

{color:#DE350B}*The question is how to   enableAuthentication if you have more than one network ?*{color}

column1: Phase 2 - Refactor HL Explorer to use minimal network configuration
column32:
Use default peer, and channel to connect to a fabric network, and use discovery to get:
channel/peers profiles, configurations, and other attributes using Fabric SDK for Node.

Lates API that provides a different approach of connecting using a Gateway

https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.4/developapps/connectionprofile.html

Some to take in consideration: 
- It’s not necessary to list all the peers in config.json, but It’s good practice to have multiple peers to avoid single points of failure.
- organizations can be in multiple channels, and channels can have multiple organizations. 


Mutual TLS
https://fabric-sdk-node.github.io/tutorial-mutual-tls.html

column1: Locate command is incorrect on Mac OS X
column32:
Locate command produces an error due to bad syntax, in Version 3.8 / latest master

As seen here:

[https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/commit/3dc4c97d6e264b4a48d1ff1961a906a45365c3f6#diff-b7387ecc23113bd1c1f8baf51398acbcR26]

 

The command being run is simply "locate" with no parameters, which in turn leads to errors on start up of

" 

usage: locate [-0Scims] [-l limit] [-d database] pattern ...

"

Further, there is a continuous stream of errors in the logs while running

 

"

usage: locate [-0Scims] [-l limit] [-d database] pattern ... 

default database: `/var/db/locate.database' or $LOCATE_PATH

locate: illegal option -- r

usage: locate [-0Scims] [-l limit] [-d database] pattern ...

"

 

The Darwin/OS X specific clause looks to drop the path, which the else clause has (as seen in the above commit). The path should be added back and/or this should be rewritten to produce a syntactically correct locate command

2) Remove the link from the UI CHAINCODE page, see attached printscreen chaincode_link {color}

column1: Configure explorer with fabcar sample
column32:
Instruction how to start fabcar provided https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.4/understand_fabcar_network.html

Follow up instructions after running script ./startFabric.sh 

Next, use the FabCar applications to interact with the deployed FabCar contract.
The FabCar applications are available in multiple programming languages.
Follow the instructions for the programming language of your choice:

JavaScript:

  Start by changing into the "javascript" directory:
    cd javascript

  Next, install all required packages:
    $npm install

  Then run the following applications to enroll the admin user, and register a new user
  called user1 which will be used by the other applications to interact with the deployed
  FabCar contract:
    $node enrollAdmin
    $node registerUser

  You can run the invoke application as follows. By default, the invoke application will
  create a new car, but you can update the application to submit other transactions:
    $node invoke

  You can run the query application as follows. By default, the query application will
  return all cars, but you can update the application to evaluate other transactions:
    $node query

I was able to successfully run the balance transfer example network on Kubernetes before. (well, not exactly the balance transfer example. My network has three orderers instead of one). Now I want to bring BE into my cluster but I got this error:
{quote}postgres://hppoc:password@explorerdb:5432/fabricexplorer
 /bin/sh: locate: not found

 ReferenceError: host_port is not defined
 at FabricClient.initializeChannelFromDiscover (/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/FabricClient.js:404:17)
 at <anonymous>
 Received kill signal, shutting down gracefully
 Closed out connections
{quote}
 

And this is my config.json:

[^config.json]

{{^I think I can telnet to all peers and orderers from explorer container! Well, the thing is when I telnet to some container this is what happens:^ }}

Console escape. Commands are:

e     exit telnet 

Entering character mode 

Escape character is '^]'. 

Connection closed by foreign host

But I don't think this is a problem 'cause this also happens in docker environment (where I was able to successfully deploy BE).

The following is from /opt/logs/app/app.log

Thank you;;;
column174:
24/Feb/19 5:13 PM;arman19940326;No, not your sample config.json. The attached config.json that I provided needed to be fixed based on my Fabric configurations. The thing is in Kubernetes I couldn't use dots in pod/service names so I changed all dots to dashes (for example I renamed peer0.org1.example.com to peer0-org1-example-com [This is peer's url in Kubernetes environment]). In the previous attached config.json I didn't change the names of peers/orderers because I thought it's just a placeholder and the important thing is the url in each peer/orderer's definition. It turned out both the the name and the url should be the same as the peer's/orderer's url.

Why I thought the names are just placeholders? Because this is the case in network-config.yaml file. In that file I didn't change the peer/orderer names to match with their url and the app worked just fine.

This is my new config.json file:

[^config.json];;;

column1: Refactor HL Explorer to use minimal network configuration
column32:
Use default peer, and channel to connect to a fabric network, and use discovery to get:
channel/peers profiles, configurations, and other attributes using Fabric SDK for Node.

Lates API that provides a different approach of connecting using a Gateway

https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.4/developapps/connectionprofile.html

Some to take in consideration: 
- It’s not necessary to list all the peers in config.json, but It’s good practice to have multiple peers to avoid single points of failure.
- organizations can be in multiple channels, and channels can have multiple organizations.

column1: Create login page for HLExplorer
column32:
Create login page for explorer, fields  [Login, Password], and should be provided on login page as a legend
Default user: admin
Default password: adminpw

Requirements:

Default explorer user will be the admin that is initially setup during the start up process, or by running some script.
New users will be enrolled by the admin user, or default account for HLExplorer.
The admin login credentials should be the fabric-ca admin, or other user credentials that are defined in:  blockchain-explorer/app/platform/fabric/config_ca.json file.

We have two modes for TLS [enabled, disabled]

Call to rest api should we on initial page load, with evaluation of the response from REST API '/api/login'
 1) TLS disabled proceed to explorer dashboard page
2) TLS enabled return login page, user should enter default admin credentials


Add configuration to  file : blockchain-explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json
options:   "enableAuthentication": false|true

{color:#DE350B}*The question is how to   enableAuthentication if you have more than one network ?*{color}

column1: Configure HLExplorer to work with fabric-ca and first-network
column32:
This is a clone of BE-485 and being created to make sure this works for first-network also.  Leaving in the backlog for now. Once a developer is ready to work on this, description needs to be updated to reflect the work to be done.

Requests from many developers to be able to run HLExplorer with fabric-ca server.

1) Use fabric-ca client and admin credentials to login to fabric-ca server.
 2) Enroll HLExplorer user to fabric-ca, and store the generated user credentials in a temp directory, can be under explorer
 3) Verify if user exists on the CA, if they do not, register them.
 4) Verify if user exists credentials (key/cert pair) exist before enrolling, and that credentials are valid, otherwise re-enroll the HLExplorer user.
 5) Minimize or avoid using CMD tools for generating credentials or enroll HLExplorer user, we want as less as possible use of command tools.

Balance transfer sample has a fabric-ca server, [https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-samples/tree/master/balance-transfer#sample-rest-apis-requests] , and can be used top test explorer

column1: Add docker-compose.yaml for making easy to use container images
column32:
As it has already discussed on the gerrit below, we need to provide more information for using explorer with docker-compose without deploy_explorer.sh.
* [Change Ie8a12ae7: Allow Postgre entrypoint usage from a docker-compose|https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/27715/]

Steps
* Create docker-compose.yaml for starting up explorer and explorer-db containers.
* Mount createdb.sh script under /docker-entrypoint-initdb.d on explorer-db container.
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column171:
23/Jan/19 10:42 AM;hoefling;If this will help, this is the {{deploy_explorer.sh}} script (roughly) translated to a {{docker-compose.yml}} I'm using for monitoring:

{code}
version: '3.5'

services:
  blockchain-explorer-db:
    container_name: blockchain-explorer-db
    image: my/explorer-db
    build: ./db
    networks:
      fabric-explorer-net:
        ipv4_address: 192.168.10.11
    environment:
      - DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc
      - DATABASE_PASSWORD=password 
      - DATABASE_DATABASE=fabricexplorer
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD-SHELL", "pg_isready -U postgres"]
      interval: 10s
      timeout: 5s
      retries: 5

  explorer:
    container_name: blockchain-explorer
    image: hyperledger/explorer
    command:
      - /bin/sh
      - -c
      - |
        apk update
        apk add curl
        # see https://jira.hyperledger.org/projects/BE/issues/BE-517
        sed -i 's/const shutDown \= function () {/const shutDown = function (exitCode) {/; s/process.exit(0)/process.exit(exitCode)/; s/shutDown();/shutDown(1);/' /opt/explorer/main.js
        node /opt/explorer/main.js
    ports:
      - "8090:8080"
    environment:
      - DATABASE_HOST=192.168.10.11
      - DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc
      - DATABASE_PASSWD=password
    volumes:
      - ./config.json:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json
      - ./crypto:/tmp/crypto
    depends_on:
      - blockchain-explorer-db
    restart: on-failure
    networks:
      fabric-explorer-net:
        ipv4_address: 192.168.10.12
      default:
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD-SHELL", "curl -f http://localhost:8080 || exit 1 "]
      interval: 10s
      timeout: 5s
      retries: 5

networks:
  default:
    name: composer_default
    external:
      name: composer_default
  fabric-explorer-net:
    name: fabric-explorer-net
    ipam:
      driver: default
      config:
        - subnet: 192.168.10.0/24
{code}

I extend the original {{hyperledger/explorer-db}} image to avoid the explicit execution of {{createdb.sh}}:

{code}
FROM hyperledger/explorer-db

RUN cp ./createdb.sh /docker-entrypoint-initdb.d/
RUN adduser postgres wheel
RUN echo '%wheel ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD:ALL' >> /etc/sudoers
{code}

The {{sudoers}} manipulation is necessary because {{createdb.sh}} uses it in the Linux case (although the user is already {{postgres}} in the container).

Another thing is the ugly monkeypatching of the code in the {{hyperledger/explorer}} container; I created a separate issue BE-517 for that.;;;

column1: Create 'Wallet'  generator utility
column32:
We will need a utility, or script to create a wallet, 
see https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.4/developapps/designelements.html, I think fabcar sample has some steps on how to.

Questions we need to answer:
- Where the wallet will be stored (file system, db, ldap?)
    A: We plan to store the wallet in file system using FileSystemWallet 
- How do we generate the wallet (maybe a setup script, or other)
   A: is done by the provided API 
- Who will add to the walle a new registered user
  A:  this would be the admin role, in our case admin will be the application service account 
- How do we handle user updates, like changing the role, revoking the role, and how we handle multiple user roles
   To find out 
- Best practices how to use, and or generate a wallet, any other suggestion from SDK for Node HLFabric development team 
   To research

column32:
Requests from many developers to be able to run HLExplorer with fabric-ca server.

1) Use fabric-ca client and admin credentials to login to fabric-ca server.
 2) Enroll HLExplorer user to fabric-ca, and store the generated user credentials in a temp directory, can be under explorer

column176:
18/Jan/19 3:39 PM;nekia;h2. Setup for using source code
 * Setup and startup balance-transfer environment
 ** Using fabric-samples release-1.3
 ** Just following [this steps|https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-samples/tree/release-1.3/balance-transfer#option-2]
 * Modify app/platform/fabric/config.json of blockchain-explorer
 ** I've already changed it to balance-transfer example based. Basically you just only need to change cert path.
 * Start explorer
 ** The steps described [here |https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer]are also needed (`Database Setup` and `Build Hyperledger Explorer`)
 ** By default, user ID 'hlbeuser' will be registered and enrolled.
 ** Access to localhost:8080

h2. Setup for using docker image
 * Modify container name of ca servers on balance-transfer network
 ** By default, they are named as 'ca_peerOrg1' and 'ca_peerOrg2'. Because of the following problem, I failed to access from explorer to ca-server.
 *** [Overlay network host names are case sensitive in Docker DNS · Issue #993 · docker/libnetwork|https://github.com/docker/libnetwork/issues/993]
 ** So I just changed to other container name without using any capital letters ( like ca.org1.example.com ).
 * Setup and startup balance-transfer environment
 ** Using fabric-samples release-1.3
 ** Just following [this steps|https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-samples/tree/release-1.3/balance-transfer#option-2]
 * Build container image for explorer locally 
 ** docker build -t hyperledger/explorer .
 * Copy crypto artifacts to examples/net/crypto
 * Start explorer and explorer-db container
 ** ./deploy_explorer.sh net1 artifacts_default
 ** Access to localhost:8090;;;

column1: Explorer is only showing one peer while my network have 8
column32:
Hyperledger Explorer 0.3.7
Image: From dockerhub (not generating one)
Hyperledger Fabric: 1.3.0

I have 4 Orgs (Org1MSP to Org4MSP) with 2 peers on each org, that are:
blockchain-org1peer1
blockchain-org1peer2
blockchain-org2peer1
blockchain-org2peer2
blockchain-org3peer1
blockchain-org3peer2
blockchain-org4peer1
blockchain-org4peer2

All the peers are enrolled on the channel, as I've confimed it with "peer channel list" on each one, and all replied ok. Also they are all running on 1.3.0 version. I've attached everything that I could, but the logs for app and db are really big, so I've attached the beggining of those.
Thanks
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column172:
20/Nov/18 11:13 PM;nfrunza;Incase someone face the same situation, see the suggested configuration, you may need to update to your fabric specific, the steps are:

Have the anchorpeers set on your configtx, and:
configtxgen -profile FourOrgsOrdererGenesis -outputBlock genesis.block

configtxgen -profile FourOrgsChannel -outputAnchorPeersUpdate ./Org1MSPanchors.tx -channelID channel1 -asOrg Org1MSP
configtxgen -profile FourOrgsChannel -outputAnchorPeersUpdate ./Org2MSPanchors.tx -channelID channel1 -asOrg Org2MSP
configtxgen -profile FourOrgsChannel -outputAnchorPeersUpdate ./Org3MSPanchors.tx -channelID channel1 -asOrg Org3MSP
configtxgen -profile FourOrgsChannel -outputAnchorPeersUpdate ./Org4MSPanchors.tx -channelID channel1 -asOrg Org4MSP

on blockchain-org1peer1:
peer channel update -f /shared/Org1MSPanchors.tx -c channel1 -o blockchain-orderer:31010 
on blockchain-org2peer1:
peer channel update -f /shared/Org2MSPanchors.tx -c channel1 -o blockchain-orderer:31010
on blockchain-org3peer1:
peer channel update -f /shared/Org3MSPanchors.tx -c channel1 -o blockchain-orderer:31010
on blockchain-org4peer1:
peer channel update -f /shared/Org4MSPanchors.tx -c channel1 -o blockchain-orderer:31010 

For each peer:
CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_BOOTSTRAP: blockchain-org1peer1:30110
CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_ENDPOINT: blockchain-org1peer1:30110
CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNALENDPOINT: blockchain-org1peer1:30110
CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_ORGLEADER: "false"
CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_SKIPHANDSHAKE: "true"
CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_USELEADERELECTION: "true;;;
column173:
20/Nov/18 11:15 PM;nfrunza;Not an explorer bug, it is more a fabric miss-configuration
 
[~feitnomore] Great job;;;

column1: Test Explorer for reading Private data
column32:
1) Use guidance from https://fabric-sdk-node.github.io/tutorial-private-data.html to setup fabric samples or any other fabric 1.2 network, or use any provided samples by fabric, or provided in https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-6600

2) Configure Explorer with the network (configured for private data), and try to run explorer.
3) Submit transactions to the configured fabric with private data, use tools like CLI
4) Test explorer for reading private data

Use release-3.7 branch for development

Some scripts to use
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/tree/release-1.2/examples/e2e_cli

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qyjDi93URJE

column1: Test existing v0.3.7 with fabric-1.3 rc
column32:
Based on email received from fabric Hyperledger Fabric maintainers, see below, we need to try to test Explorer.

1) Install fabric 1.3 rc locally
2) Configure explorer with fabric 1.3 rc 
3) Perform test


Excerpt from email sent by "David Enyeart enyeart@us.ibm.com via lists.hyperledger.org 
Wed, Sep 26, 3:38 PM "

The Hyperledger Fabric maintainers are pleased to announce the first Release Candidate for version v1.3!

See what's new in v1.3 at https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.3/whatsnew.html.

Download Hyperledger Fabric and Hyperledger Fabric CA v1.3.0-rc1, binaries and docker images here: 
https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.3/install.html

Please give v1.3.0-rc1 a try - we will be monitoring and quickly resolving any issues reported to Hyperledger JIRA ( https://jira.hyperledger.org/ ), so that we can make a final v1.3 announcement as soon as possible.

Refer to the release notes for more details:
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/releases/tag/v1.3.0-rc1
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-ca/releases/tag/v1.3.0-rc1

Contact us via this Hyperledger Fabric mailing list ( https://lists.hyperledger.org/g/fabric ) or RocketChat ( https://chat.hyperledger.org/ ) should you have any feedback or questions.

column1: Creation of Docker images for Explorer
column32:
Creation of official Docker images (PostgreSQL and Explorer containers) in the official Hyperledger Docker Hub. As HF distributes its components in Docker, the Explorer should also ship as Docker containers.

Each new commit to the master branch (stable release) should have its image available in Docker Hub.

May also provide templates for deploying the explorer in Kubernetes.
column171: 05/Oct/18 1:06 AM;nfrunza;this is a duplicate, will close this jira subtask ;;;

column1: Fix insecure websocket warning running under https
column32:
Fix insecure websocket warning running under https

The websocket listener for Explorer used insecure protocol (ws:)
which causes most modern browsers to block or at least warn as
insecure when running under https. This patch switches to secure
protocol (wss:) when the explorer is launched under a https endpoint

column1: Properties file modification breaks Dockerfile configuration
column32:
Getting the DB properties from a file makes the docker configuration of the BE-42 break, because its DB properties are hardcoded like pre-BE-415 ones. Dockerfile must be changed to take DB properties from file like post-BE-415 ones.

! Fix needs to be applied for tag v0.3.5

column1: INDEX error with postgreSQL when saving large data
column32:
If you store a large amount of data in the transaction's write set, such as a Base64 encoded picture, it will cause an index error in postgreSQL and the Explorer will crash.

 

 (-) -DROP INDEX IF EXISTS transaction_chaincode_proposal_input_idx- now so Explorer works, but the transaction details dialog box gets stuck because the write set is large。

column1: Support non TLS in fab-1.2-integration branch
column32:
Excerpt from https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-443

----
I noticed the existence of 'fab-1.2-integration' branch.
Certainly it's already been able to do some validation of config.json.

*How to run fabric in non TLS mode*
git clone https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-samples.git
cd fabric-sample/first-network
git checkout release-1.2
find -iregex '.*\.yaml$' | xargs sed -i -e "s/TLS_ENABLED=true/*TLS_ENABLED=false*/g"
./byfn.sh generate
./byfn.sh up
When run blockchain explorer on 'fab-1.2-integration' branch and fabric 1.2 network( non TLS. config.json ), I got the following error.

[2018-08-21 23:26:26.124] [ERROR] FabricUtils - TLS CA Certs path is not defined default peer [peer0.org1.example.com] in configuration
-------

column1: Create, deploy, and instantiate a chaincode to test Explorer with large data
column32:
1) Create a chaincode to support large data input, add chaincode source code in devenv/src/chaincode/test
2) Clone script from blockchain-explorer/devenv/scripts/create-channel-join-insert-transaction.sh to blockchain-explorer/devenv/scripts/large-data-chaincode-channel-join-insert-transaction.sh 
3) If chaincode already deployed and instantiated skip to creating new transactions
4) Modify the script to use new developed chaincode, and deploy,  instantiate  on existing mychannel
5) Create a sample file in  blockchain-explorer/devenv/data/sample-data.txt (only when running script blockchain-explorer/devenv/scripts/large-data-chaincode-channel-join-insert-transaction.sh modify sample-data.txt to up to 90MB of data, and not to be saved in Git)
6) Modify the script to create transactions using blockchain-explorer/devenv/data/sample-data.txt (up to 90MB of data)
7) Code to be added to the new release-3.6 branch after it has merged from fab-1.2-integration branch

Instructions:

column1: View the status of each node, blocks sync status, throughput
column32:
Health Check.

To objectively measure the health of a peer/node we can check on the following things.
 # Block sync status and compare it to other peers/nodes
 # Throughput available for syncing the blocks

These metrics may not be readily available via the NodeSDK and even at the peer. This story needs these metrics to be available in Fabric Peer.

column1: Add support for process.env variables in creating database script
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column171:
30/Aug/18 9:11 PM;srinivas640;[~nfrunza] :  Please check below suggested changes.

1) a .env file is created with the following properties.

DATABASE_DATABASE=fabricexplorer
DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc
DATABASE_PASSWD=password

2) if node js environment requires the properties npm module dotenv will be installed and read these values in java script using  like process.env.DATABASE_DATABASE.

3) createdb.sh modified like below to read these values from .env file.
FILE=../../../../.env;
DATABASE_DATABASE=$(grep -i 'DATABASE_DATABASE' $FILE | cut -f2 -d'=')
DATABASE_USERNAME=$(grep -i 'DATABASE_USERNAME' $FILE | cut -f2 -d'=')
DATABASE_PASSWD=$(grep -i 'DATABASE_PASSWD' $FILE | cut -f2 -d'=')
 
export USER=$DATABASE_DATABASE || $(jq .postgreSQL.username ../../../../explorerconfig.json )
export DATABASE=$DATABASE_USERNAME||$(jq .postgreSQL.database ../../../../explorerconfig.json );;;
column172: 30/Aug/18 11:40 PM;nfrunza;Try to invoke in createdb.sh  (node process.env. DATABASE_USERNAME ) to get the value.;;;
column173: 31/Aug/18 6:39 PM;srinivas640;[~nfrunza]  node process.env. DATABASE_USERNAME will not work as node requires  js file to run.  We can open node terminal  in interactive mode and get/set process environment variables but from node js terminal/shell script, using node process.env.DATABASE_USERNAME will  yield error as  node understands that process.env .DATABASE_USERNAME as file to execute and fails. Hence i created a js file called processenv.js which will  have logic to create a json file in tmp location with process.env  values. When we run this from script using node processenv.js will read json file for corresponding database credentials and set it accordingly. If no process environment variables , it reads from pgconfig.json.  once process is completed,  script deletes temporary json file temp location. Code is delivered for your review.;;;
column174:
01/Sep/18 12:48 AM;nfrunza;Tested by setting ENV variables using CMD, and looks good
export DATABASE_HOST=127.0.0.1
export DATABASE_PORT=5432
export DATABASE_DATABASE=fabricexplorer
export DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc
export DATABASE_PASSWD=pass12345
;;;

column1: Use properties from a config file to run DDL script
column32:
This JIRA is created by the suggestion from the rocket chat, [https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=MR7YGPCajb6BmakoP]

See exerpt

Is there a way to get those values from some properties file and updating the explorerpg.sql , updatepg.sql . Instead of updating them manually ?
 nfrunza July 20, 2018 4:18 PM
 @praveentalari Will add to the README.md file, thank you for mentioning
 praveentalari July 20, 2018 2:14 AM
 @nfrunza Then github README should be updated I guess, it has mentioned
 * "Modify pgconfig.json to update postgresql properties

pg host, port, database, username, password details." *

but nothing about changes required in explorerpg.sql

If the changes are done only in pgconfig.json,
 the following steps don't work as expected.
 * "Run create database script.

\i app/persistence/postgreSQL/db/explorerpg.sql
 \i app/persistence/postgreSQL/db/updatepg.sql" *

 

Use process.env properties to get in explorerpg.sql

host": process.env.DATABASE_HOST || pgconfig.host,
 "port": process.env.DATABASE_PORT || pgconfig.port,
 "database": process.env.DATABASE_DATABASE || pgconfig.database,
 "username": process.env.DATABASE_USERNAME || pgconfig.username,
 "passwd": process.env.DATABASE_PASSWD || pgconfig.passwd

column1: Test Docker change by Blockchain Tecnalia
column32:
The [feature|https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/24559] _readme.md_ includes a brief explanation too.
For testing purposes, there are some prerequisites that needs to be fulfilled first:
 * have docker installed on target machine
 * have a valid HLF network running (for testing purposes at _localhost_ works)

To deploy the required containers, run _deploy_explorer.sh_
It will create a virtual docker network, download images from dockerhub, create custom images and deploy them.

An example of configuration file for setting right peer information (IP, port, etc.) and proper crypto material is found at examples folder under file config.json. It needs to be updated with target fabric network config.
After that, put network crypto material under net/examples/net1/crypto folder to load it successfully during deployment process.It should have the following structure: 

net1
   ├── config.json
   ├── crypto
   │   ├── ordererOrganizations
   │   │   └── readme.txt
   │   ├── peerOrganizations
   │   │   └── readme.txt
   │   └── readme.txt
   └── README.md

2.  fabricexplorer schema is not getting deployed in Database container 10.10.0.11. I changed the following to work with explorer container 10.10.0.12.

		-d \
		--name $fabric_explorer_name \
		--net $docker_network_name --ip $explorer_ip \
		-e DATABASE_HOST=$db_ip\

column1: Remove session storage from theming and use Material-UI
column100: (Please add high level design or a link to the design)
column171: 01/Aug/18 12:30 AM;spranay;MuiThemeProvide was my first consideration when I started off with the theme change, I have to later abandon this approach for multiple reasons. Using MuiThemeProvide for this particular app is not advisable as there are multiple components other than Material UI. We have React-tables, React-charts and other SVG which have to be handled closely using customized CSS styling(It is doable using MuiThemeProvide but the approach is not straight forward). The MuiThemeProvide also creates CSS objects in runtime, hence making it the same approach. Direct CSS in JS and using with props is another elegant way of doing this,I have used this for certain functionalities in here, but to keep things in convention and future proof have to come with this approach.  [~skclusive], please let me know your inputs on this.;;;
column172: 14/Aug/18 9:28 PM;skclusive;Hi [~spranay], Material-UI library has react-jss (css-in-js library) part of it. Yes if every component is of Material-UI based it would be simpler using MuiThemeProvider. For block chain explorer app where multiple component library is used (ex: reactstrap) we can still pass className parameter which is generated in the hosting material-ui component. or we can have a simple wrapper component which passes runtime generated classes to those components. ;;;

column1: Add filter components for blocks and transactions
column32:
Add UI components for both BLCOKS and TRANSACTIONS screens.

Components should be on top of the result table header and below navigation TABS, and right most aligned, see screen shots

Date From, To

Organization 

Add Search button, "SEARCH" , or capitalized 

Add RESET button

Date range should be defaulted to current timestamp minus 1 day

Organization should be a multi select with values["All", org1, org2], default value "All"

Selection applied must be default for components when they are refreshed, in this case BLOCK, and TRANSACTIONS screens.

Actions:

User clicks SEACRH button, a call to REST API will be dispatched, the selected criteria should remain in effect until user changes it, with exception the dates will be updated as stated current timestamp minus one date.

User clicks RESET button, this will reset the filter to the default values, Date From, To [current timestamp minus one day], and Organization to ["All"], and search result should be returned to UI

 

*Add validate for the FROM and TO date, for both blocks and transactions pages*

*FROM should not be greater than TO,* see printscreen

Add message: "From date should be less than To date"

 

Future dates FROM, and TO when entered do not trigger action, in this case the list should be empty but it is same as before.

See screenshots uploaded on August 14 around 10 AM

column171:
09/Aug/18 11:40 PM;nfrunza;tested, i found a cartesian product in the block list query, reworking on the SQL, should be:
 *you will need to apply org and date filters*
select (select [c.name|http://c.name/] from channel c where c.channel_genesis_hash =
        '8b44934f9df76aecbbd355a27cb97ed889653667fee8629141bf5b16357c3391' ), blocks.blocknum,blocks.txcount ,blocks.datahash ,blocks.blockhash ,blocks.prehash,blocks.createdt,(
       SELECT  array_agg(txhash) as txhash FROM transactions where blockid = blocks.blocknum  and
        channel_genesis_hash = '8b44934f9df76aecbbd355a27cb97ed889653667fee8629141bf5b16357c3391' and createdt between '2018-08-08T14:07:15.157Z' 
        and '2018-08-09T14:07:15.157Z') from blocks
      where
        blocks.channel_genesis_hash ='8b44934f9df76aecbbd355a27cb97ed889653667fee8629141bf5b16357c3391' and blocknum >= 0 and blocks.createdt between '2018-08-08T14:07:15.157Z' and '2018-08-09T14:07:15.157Z'
        order by blocks.blocknum desc;;;

column1: Separate Fabric calls from Sync
column32:
All calls that go to the Fabric Platform need to happen from the Fabric Platform Directory. Use a Proxy to route all calls to the Fabric Platform .

Have Sync folder be generic (no fabric folder) and have the SyncBuilder.js just create a Proxy object for the intended Platform. 

Place contents of sync/fabric folder into platform/fabric folder.

 

Further Discussion in meeting .

column32:
Apply same date format for block, transaction details, should be same across all screens

 

The date displayed should be

Use:

var d = new Date();, where Date object would created from the value that is retuned from the DB 
 var n = d.toISOString();

Example, we should have in UI across all screens 

2018-08-01T13:34:19.400Z

 

 

 

P.S, we may want in the future to have the date display based on some configurable date format, and not to be covered in this jira

This issue seems to be reproduced by specifying wrong channel name on app/platform/fabric/config.json intentionally.

Name the column tx_response

column1: Add Proptypes to all React Components
Write a script for creating new channels with data
column32:
Put the commands for creating a new channel and getting peer to join channel, instantiating existing chaincode on that channel ( or installing and instantiating if a new chaincode) and invoking chaincode to submit transactions to generate some data. This will make it easier for developers to test explorer with multiple channels

 

Script should be configured and run of the fabric-sample/first-network installation to have the ability to see multiple channels in the HL Explorer.

To consider the following steps:

1) Verify that there is a fabric sample docker image installed

2) export PATH's required for creating channel, join peers, chaincodes

3) Create channel, and join peer script should take the CHANNEL_NAME parameter. Instantiate default chaincode should be in the same script

4) Create a script to submit N transactions, N and the CHANNEL_NAME should be passed as parameters.

N a MAX of 10  transactions

5) commit the script in devenv/scripts
column171:
18/Jul/18 7:41 PM;srinivas640;writing script for creating a channel and creating  number of transactions is completed and testing is pending. Script needs to be placed in fabric-samples/first-network and execute
Script usage : ./create-channel-transaction.sh -c channel19 -n 1  ( -c channelname  -n number of transactions);;;
column172: 18/Jul/18 9:52 PM;nfrunza;Shrini is testing his script;;;
column173:
19/Jul/18 7:17 PM;srinivas640;Tested with explorer using the  script pointing Fabric 1.2 changing appconfig.json "version": "1.2.0" in explorer. Script is able to create a channel and insert number of transactions.
Script handles the following scenarios.
1. Checks for docker hyperledger images,configtxgen before creating a channel.
2. If a channel already exists, then proceeds with inserting N number of transactions else will create a channel and inserts records.
Script usage : ./create-channel-transaction.sh -c channel19 -n 1 ( -c channelname -n number of transactions)
Attached script.
;;;

column1: Peer information changes needed
column32:
Currently we fetch peer info from config.json file. It appears that node sdk does not at the moment provide network discovery capability for peers on the network,
Peer info is being saved to the peer table at this time. Some changes need to be made the way we are saving that information. The following changes will affect both the saving and retrieval of peer information in explorer.
1)  The mapping of peer to channel needs to be saved in peer_ref_channel table, NOT peer table.
2) While reading in info from config.json on peers,  save all the peer information in peer table and mapping of peer to channel in peer_ref_channel table. Do not save channel  name in peer.name, peer.server_name should serve the purpose of peer's name, remove peer.server_name column from peer table and store server name in name column instead. 
3) The peer list on dashboard page should show only the peers that belong to the selected channel in dropdown ( default channel name comes from config.json) and hence that info would come from a join of peer and peer_ref_channel tables. When a user chooses a different channel name in dropdown, the peer list on dashboard must refresh.

column1: Database should not contain reserved SQL words as identifiers
column32:
Please consult standards 
||SQL:2011||SQL:2008||SQL-92||

for reserved words

[https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.6/static/sql-keywords-appendix.html]

 

Table TRANSACTION should be renamed 

Any identifier defined in DDL of the the fabricexplorer schema should be renamed

Modify updatepq.sql script to update/rename identifiers.
 ALTER TABLE IF EXISTS table_name
 RENAME TO new_table_name;
  
 To rename multiple columns, you add each {{RENAME}} clause for each column, each clause is separated by a comma (,):
  
|1
 2
 3
 4|ALTER TABLE table_name
 RENAME column_name_1 TO new_column_name_1,
 RENAME column_name_2 TO new_column_name_2,
 ...;|

 

Single column
 ALTER TABLEtable_name
 RENAME column_name TO new_column_name;

column1: Timecharts not syncing after channel has been changed
REST API response analyses
column32:
Need to analyse response time from REST API calls, on low data and high volume.

Can use syncStartDate to sync into postgresql DB to load less historical data

 Prerequisirtes

High volume of data, at least 500-1000 blocks and 1000 + transactions

1) Use swagger to analyse the performance

2) Research any available plugin to inject into the code to get the performance, one of them : [https://nodejs.org/en/docs/guides/simple-profiling/]   

3) Connect to AWS network and to test

4) How to profile: [https://nodejs.org/en/docs/guides/simple-profiling/]

 

 

 

How to run Apache Bench (for ubuntu only, macOS has it installed)

1) Install Apache Bench 

2) Start HL Explorer

3) From a terminal run commands that are in file: [^report-ApacheBench.txt]

4) Before running change the request parameters to you specific channel hash, easy would be to copy the URL's from the Chrome Network tab

 

Example command: 

ab -k -c 20 -n 100 "http://localhost:8080/api/txList/cf3135f3e7844981101f78798293f9d73bee40e74a52be49ab37fbe4709a33c5/0/0" >> report.tx 

 The ">> report.tx" will append to the report file

please attach for the review
column41: Installing Apache Bench, modifying scripts and script running, analyzing the results, documenting the results and updating the Jira.;12/Jul/18 4:30 AM;spranay;14400
column42: Overall time is calculated based on reviewing, running reports in different environments and discussing the possible solutions to be applied ;12/Jul/18 4:40 AM;nfrunza;144000
column171:
26/Jun/18 4:22 AM;nfrunza;Findings

I setup explorer to run in profiling mode, start.js add
NODE_ENV=development node --prof main.js >>logs/console/console.log-"$(date +%Y-%m-%d)" 2>&1 &
 
After the start you will see a file starting with isolate-XXXXXXXXXXX-v8.log in root directory
 
Run the command : node --prof-process isolate-XXXXXXXXXXX-v8.log > processed.txt

See the result, 

ticks parent  name

    644   33.5%  T ___kdebug_trace_string

I did google and the upgrade of node to 8.11.2 introduced a slow performance, see [https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49726695/horrible-performance-when-upgrading-from-node-v6-7-0-to-v8-11-1]

 

Our test would be to switch to node 6.9 and rerun the same test

 

 

 
 ;;;

column1: Transaction details modal shows the same transaction hash

Steps to reproduce
 Navigate to transaction list tab
 Click on any transaction to preview transaction details
 Transaction hash is showing the same as previous for a few seconds before it refreshes.
Two possible things we can do:
 1) Set the data object for transactions details to an empty object when the user clicks on X to close the modal
 2) Put a spinner until the incoming data loads
