column1: View transaction payload information
column32:
Implement queryTransaction API call from ledger. 
1) capture transaction validation code into transactions table. Save the text, not the int, look at https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/v1.0.0/protos/peer/transaction.proto#L125 for txValidationCode enum.
2) There are byte arrays in the json response. One for the signature of the entity that signed the transaction, then there is one for chaincode_proposal_payload.input, and then there is one for the endorser signature. Can we convert to text and capture this info too in the database? If yes, then add these fields to the transactions details model.

column1: Historical Data Retrieval for peers
column32:
Decide on the back-end process to run one time when brining up HL Explorer - Retreive Historical Data for new peers. Assignee needs to do analysis to determine best way to accomplish this goal.  

To sync data historically configure syncStartDate in file:

blockchain-explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json

 
to format "YYYY/MM/DD", example: 
    "syncStartDate":"2018/06/20",

column171:
12/Jun/18 10:12 PM;jojialex2;The Hyperledger fabric administrator grpc  service getStatus() (status of the peer) is not implemented by the fabric-client and the Peer have only a single grpc service ProcessProposal () and it is used for following activities and we can pass list of peers to these services

            

JoinChannel

SendUpgradeProposal

SendTransactionProposal 

installChainCode

 

I checked the fabric client code, it’s adding each peer result into an array and returning, even if there is an error, we can use this services or an workaround like implement the Admin getStatus() service in explorer  to get the peer status.

 

Solution Approach decided as below 

 

For implement the Admin getStatus() service

 

{color:#1f497d}We can create new class and extends the Remote, then we can implement admin.protos service where in fabric-client in the new class.{color}

 

 

 

 

 ;;;

column1: Implement file upload for channel creation
column32:
Add the ability to upload (channel).tx and (channel).block files to create channel and peers to join channel

 
Create channel
=======



# Requirements
Setup your own network if you do not have it using [Build your network](http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/build_network.html) tutorial from Fabric.

# Generate binary config files
-Use the configtxgen tool to produce the binary config files.
From the sample directory fabric-samples/

-Setup FABRIC_CFG_PATH
`export FABRIC_CFG_PATH=$PWD`
`./bin/configtxgen -outputBlock channelname.block -profile TwoOrgsOrdererGenesis`
`./bin/configtxgen -channelID channelname -outputCreateChannelTx channelname.tx -profile TwoOrgsChannel`

**channelname is the name of your channel you want to create

-Update "fabric-path" in file /blockchain-explorer/app/config/network-config-tls.yaml to your fabric network path

-Everytime you create a new channel you need to define it in file:
/blockchain-explorer/app/config/network-config-tls.yaml
Search for keyword newchannel, and update it to the name of your new channel

- Use Web UI ADMIN PANEL to create and manage a channel

[More on "How to create a Hyperledger Fabric channel"](https://fabric-sdk-node.github.io/tutorial-channel-create.html )

column1: Implement a generic blockchain explorer which can work with any Blockchain platform
column32:
Overview
------------
Blockchain explorer provides a dashboard for viewing information about transactions, blocks, node logs, statistics,  and smart contracts available on the network. Users will be able to query for specific blocks or transactions and view the complete details. Blockchain explorer can also be integrated with any authentication/authorization platforms (commercial/open source) and will provided appropriate functionality based on the privileges available to the user. 

Goals
-------
* To implement a generic Blockchain explorer web application which is easy to install and can be used with different Blockchain platforms.
* Use latest tools and technologies that make the explorer easy to implement, maintain and extend.
* Easily installable package available through standard package managers for most popular platforms.

column1: Add channel backend implementation
column32:
See -BE-156-, Ashish did analysis, you can implement in the node backend

Add a channel service under  blockchain-explorer/service

 
SETUP instructions for create new channel

SET PATH to configtxgen tool in your .bashrc file

On ubnuntu, you can use command
$sudo nano ~/.bashrc
export FABRIC_CFG_PATH=fabric-path/fabric-samples/first-network
export PATH=$PATH:$FABRIC_CFG_PATH
save the file and refresh, use command
$source ~/.bashrc

Update config.json file, look for the key configtxgenToolPath, should match your
configtxgen tool path

Update "fabric-path" in file /blockchain-explorer/app/config/network-config-tls.yaml to your
fabric network path

Everytime you add a new channel you need to define it in file:
/blockchain-explorer/app/config/network-config-tls.yaml
Search for keyword newchannel, and update it to the name of your new channel

column1: Analysis to create and join channel
column171:
07/Mar/18 3:43 PM;akuma921;From the frontend prospective there will be :

1. An action initiator (button etc.) to create the channel

2. An input screen to capture channel_name, profile_name etc.

 

!channel_creation.png|thumbnail!

3. On the channel screen, there will be a add peer action to add the required peers (by selecting them from selectbox etc.)

 

!Adding_peers.png|thumbnail!  

 

From the backend these are the steps to create a channel

1. create channel configuration file (.tx)

We need to have fabric platform binaries ('/bin') on the BE hosted machine, as this will be used to create the '.tx' file.

 
{code:java}
bin/configtxgen -profile {profile_name} -outputCreateChannelTx {channel_name}.tx -channelID {channel_name}
{code}
 

This can be achieved by running a bash command from node side using 'exec', and exit code need to be captured to make sure the command ran successfully.

Before this we have to have the required profile for the configtxgen tool. This can be done from configtx.yml file. We can have a predefined configtx.yml in BE hosted machine, with the profile definition in it. We can read/parse this configtx.yml file to provide all the available profiles for the input selection (Front End step #2).

We have to store this .tx file (as BLOB etc.) in postgres DB with channel_name as the key.

Note: The FABRIC_CFG_PATH need to be set before creating '.tx' file, and the path need to be set till crypto folder.

 

!Screen Shot 2018-03-07 at 12.13.21 PM.png|thumbnail!  

 

2. create channel (or channel .block) file

The channel can be created from fabric-sdk-node provided API, please refer:

[https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-samples/blob/release/balance-transfer/app/create-channel.js]
 [https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-node/blob/release/fabric-client/lib/Client.js] (createChannel method)

 

3. Getting peer join the channel

We can use fabric-sdk-node API to pass a peer list to join a specific channel. This API internally fatch genesis block from the channel, and then add the requested peers to the channel. please refer:

[https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-samples/blob/release/balance-transfer/app/join-channel.js]
 [https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-node/blob/release/fabric-client/lib/Channel.js] (joinChannel method)

 

!flowchart.png|thumbnail!

 

{color:#d04437}Assumption/Open Items{color}

{color:#d04437}As already discussed in standups as well, we are assuming that the crypto material to create the '.tx' will be avaible on BE hosted machine. In actual production grade scenarios, it will be questioned to have all the org's crypto-material at one common place. This need to be think from fabric-core side, and BE will incorporate this accordingly.{color};;;

I have setup the network such that the orderer and a peer (peer0) are running on one server (server1), and another peer (peer1) is running on another server (server2). I am able to bring up all these entities (with little bit of manual workaround). However, when I try to update peer1 (running on server2) as the anchor node of a channel, it is still looking for the orderer as "orderer.example.com".

When I started the peer, I started it with the "–orderer <server 1>" command. If I bring down the orderer on server 1, peer1 doesn't start and complains that it is unable to connect to orderer on server 1. So the issue doesn't exist when I start the peer. The issue exists when I am try to update the peer1 as the anchor node. Instead of orderer@server2, it "defaults" to orderer.example.com and complains that it cannot connect to this orderer.

Any leads on what the issue might be?;;;

column1: Resolve licensing issues discovered by Fossology scan
column32:
h1. Context

Hyperledger Explorer source files (from April 3, 2018) were scanned by The Linux Foundation utilizing Fossology to determine license for files contained in the following repositories:
 *  https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/blockchain-explorer

From the Hyperledger Charter (https://www.hyperledger.org/about/charter) Section 13, all files that are included in Hyperledger projects should either be licensed with the Apache License, Version 2.0 for source code or Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License for documentation.
h1. Expected Behavior

All files should have license text included either directly or via a LICENSE file in the directory for files that cannot be modified to include a comment with the license text (think binary files).
h1. Actual Behavior

See attached results of the scan.
h1. To Fix

The package metadata files (generally bower.json / package.json for NPM) incorrectly describe the Hyperledger Explorer as licensed under ISC, rather than Apache. NPM's default is ISC so this is a common mistake. I've highlighted these instances in the attached reports. These files should be changed from ISC to Apache-2.0.

For files with Attribution license, ideally, we would replace those with Apache 2.0 files and dependencies; otherwise, we will need to go to the Hyperledger Governing board for an exception.

For _ALL_ files that do not have a license included, the first step is to check with the contributor to ensure that the file can be released as Apache 2.0 or CC-BY-4.0. If the contributor agrees, the file should be modified to include the license. You can utilize [SPDX Identifiers |https://spdx.org/]to represent the correct license.

For those non-modifiable files, you will need to include a LICENSE file in the directory containing the license that the files are covered by. Here are a few examples of how this might be done:
* [OPNFV Apex|https://github.com/opnfv/apex/blob/master/LICENSE.rst] -- this is an example of explicitly calling out Apache 2.0 for source code and CC-BY-4.0 for docs. 
* [containerd|https://github.com/containerd/containerd/blob/master/README.md] -- see notice at bottom. This also calls out the separate Apache / CC-BY-4.0 docs, and explicitly references the "docs" directory.
h1. *Before closing this bug, please let me know that you have made the above changes. I will then run the code through Fossology again* *to ensure the changes.*
column172: 11/Apr/18 9:43 PM;Jdipiazz;Nik submitted patch and we are waiting on Tracy Hurt to run Fossology Scan again to ensure it passes before we mark the item as DONE.;;;
column174: 12/Apr/18 9:37 PM;Jdipiazz;Nik pending merge to Master Branch. We agreed to keep open till this is done.;;;
column175: 12/Apr/18 9:39 PM;Jdipiazz;All files should have license text included either directly or via a LICENSE file in the directory for files that cannot be modified to include a comment with the license text (think binary files).;;;

column1: Merge release-3 into master branch
column32:
Before merge verify:

1) Instructions and steps in README document

2) Code should have unit tests front and back-end 

3) Install, run tests and build instructions

4) Config instruction to connect to other networks, must be tested 

5) README document should have a reference to troubleshooting notes, rocket chat:  [https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/blockchain-explorer] , etc

6) Merged code must be installed, build and run before committing it to master

column1: Update blockchain hyperledger explorer description
column32:
Based on rocket-chat from @akshaynet we need to correct the text and assign to Tracy Kuhrt, and she will forward to WEB team to update 

i did ask in the chat and @lucasdf pointed out that these were in the hyperledger explorer and were remove by this commit: [https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/commit/b8ac105c44ca678550bf365a765863a2f8ab83a7]

As per the capabilities mentioned at - [https://www.hyperledger.org/projects/explorer] - through hyperledger-explorer we can view, invoke, deploy or query blocks, transactions and associated data, network information (name, status, list of nodes), chain codes and transaction families, as well as any other relevant information stored in the ledger. I have successfully installed the explorer following the instructions given at [https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer]. But I can see only view optoins for PEERS, BLOCKS, TRANSACTIONS, etc., but there is no option for deploy, query or invoke. Looking for help on this from the fellow members of this group.

 

 

TODO:

Text needs to be edited to reflect the current capabilities of the Hyperledger Explorer

See text  [https://www.hyperledger.org/projects/explorer]  and in attached image
column173: 29/Mar/18 2:05 AM;adamk1230;Alternate text has been drafted.  Waiting for team approval before sending to Tracy.;;;
column174:
03/Apr/18 9:56 PM;adamk1230;New text to be sent to Tracy is as follows.



Hyperledger Blockchain Explorer is a blockchain module and one of the Hyperledger projects hosted by The Linux Foundation. Designed to create a user-friendly Web application, Hyperledger Blockchain Explorer can view, invoke, deploy or query blocks, transactions and associated data, network information (name, status, list of nodes), chain codes and transaction families, as well as any other relevant information stored in the ledger. Hyperledger Blockchain Explorer was initially contributed by IBM, Intel and DTCC.  Check the current status of Hyperledger Blockchain Explorer [here|https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README.md].;;;

README files typically are located under the root of your project, and include information on:
 * Project description
 * Project requirements
 * Project and directory structure
 * How to get started with the project
 * Instructions on setup, build, and run

  Read more 
 * GithubGuides [https://guides.github.com/features/wikis/]
 * Markdown cheatsheet [https://guides.github.com/pdfs/markdown-cheatsheet- online.pdf|https://guides.github.com/pdfs/markdown-cheatsheet-%20online.pdf]

 
 * Editor can be any of your choice either on-line or plug-ins to your editors

column1: Details page for transactions
column32:
This will be called from block details page or the transaction stream.

Clicking on a transaction(with txid), this page should display the information:

1. Tx_id ( transaction hash)

2. Submitter (client)

3. Endorser peers (infer based on signatures)

4. Orderer (infer based on orderer signature)

5. Timestamp of submission

6. Timestamp of proposal ( will need to extract out of chaincode-proposal element)

7. Type of transaction (query, configuration)

8. Transaction status ( txvalidationcode: invalid, valid, etc.)

9. Chaincode name

10. Read set

11. Write set

column173:
13/Mar/18 6:17 PM;akuma921;at present, as per document below is the API details:

 

GET /api/tx/getinfo -> /api/transaction/<txid>

request payload \{"txid": <txid>}

response 

\{

  "tx_id": "header.channel_header.tx_id",

  "timestamp": "header.channel_header.timestamp",

  "channel_id": "header.channel_header.channel_id",

  "type": "header.channel_header.type"

}

 

 

We can add below as well:

"chaincode"

"creator_msp"

 

 

Also, we can add a check on validation_code as well to return meaning full results in case of failure.

 

[https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/v1.0.0/protos/peer/transaction.proto#L125]

 

 

 ;;;

column1: FIX API calls to return ALL data and also fix the endpoint URL names
column32: There are two things being addressed here. One is that the current API calls are not returning all data available. Second is that the endpoint URLs need to be a little more clear and in line with standards around REST APi calls.

column1: Change API https method calls from POST to GET
column32:
This is to stay in compliance with the standards around RESTFUL API calls.

Create --> Post

Read --> Get

Update --> PUT or PATCH

Delete -->  Delete

Since we are only querying data in our calls right now, they should all be GET not POST

Add error handling, log errors

Return HTTP STATUS

column1: Add back-end API metrics for transaction
column32:
Create backend API to retrieve transaction metrics by intervals:

1) By minute
2) By hour(s)
3) By day(s)
4) By week(s) 
5) By month(s) 
6) By Year(s)

Create sql queries for the above and  return results in JSON format

21/Feb/18 4:11 AM;rameshthoomu;Below change address this issue.. Closing this for now..

 
{code:java}
 
#!/bin/bash -e
set -o pipefail

echo "---> Run npm tests"
npm config set prefix ~/npm && npm install -g mocha && npm install chai && npm install
cd app/test && npm install
npm run test

if [ "$GERRIT_BRANCH" != "master" ]; then
     echo "====> GERRIT_BRANCH: = $GERRIT_BRANCH"
     cd ../../client && npm install
     npm test -- -u --coverage && npm run build
fi
{code}

column1: Generic Blockchain explorer UI : Implement live statistics in the Blockchain explorer using websockets protocol and POSTGRES DB.
column32:
Websocket API will be used to push information from the server to the clients. Information about new transactions, blocks, node logs etc. are pushed via Websocket API. This is a convenient API that reduces load on clients and server. POSTGRES will address API service using DB.

scoket.io will be used to implement the the websockets API in the explorer. Socket.IO enables real-time event-based communication between one or more clients and a server. It works on every platform, browser or device and is fast and reliable. It's often used in analytics, document collaboration, streaming and instant messaging.

column1: List of enrolled users and certs
Necessity for first-network to be available in the source code
column32:
Thank you for the great tool. It's super helpful. However, I think it's not a good idea to have the first-network directory within the source code repository. There should rather be enough and clear documentation detailing out how to use/setup the blockchain explorer and redirect them to the fabric-samples or example setup in fabric if the user has stumbled upon the explorer first so that the user can spin up the blockchain network.

 

The major advantage this enables is that the code from first-network doesn't go stale in this repository if the samples repository gets updated.

column1: Generic Blockchain explorer back-end : Implement Node JS web server using Express. Implement websockets for updates and stats. Implement dynamic module load needed for each Blockchain implementatio
column32:
Node.js will be the backend framework for implementing the server-side components. Express Node.js framework will be used for the web application. These tools are used as they are robust, easy to develop and maintain.

Implement server side websockets support using Socket.IO. Socket.IO enables real-time event-based communication between one or more clients and a server. It works on every platform, browser or device and is fast and reliable. It's often used in analytics, document collaboration, streaming and instant messaging.

column1: Generic Blockchain explorer UI : Implement front end using Bootstrap version 3.3, Jade templates 1.11.0 and Angular JS version 2
column32:
AngularJS will be used to implement the front-end framework. AngularJS features like
data-binding and directives greatly help in developing reusable components and
modular code. Bootstrap will be used for front-end for its rich UI and responsive
features.

Jade is the templating engine that will be used for customizing the pages based on user
permissions and roles.

column1: Remove fabric-docker-compose-svt/release
column32:
In our latest license scan of Hyperledger Explorer source code, we found a number of binary files in the [https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/tree/master/fabric-docker-compose-svt/release] directory. It appears that these files were checked in with the following commit: [https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/commit/e9fc4ecfcf4bc50bf625b90e3a48fedf323a29ce].
 
I reached out to Shouhe Wu – the author of this commit. He said that it would be okay to remove the files in fabric-docker-compose-svt/release.

column1: install instructions in readme need sudo
column32:
The README for explorer_1 has the following
npm install npm bower grunt-cli graceful-fs@4.1.5 minimatch@3.0.2 -g

for me, I needed to run it as sudo
sudo npm install npm bower grunt-cli graceful-fs@4.1.5 minimatch@3.0.2 -g

Maybe we should advise that if the first form fails, that the user should use sudo.

column1: Blockchain Explorer Upgrade recommendations
column32:
Fabric v1.0 has been released. we have the basis of fabric v1.0 has been updated above the blockchain explorer. The current project demo has been running.
 
We mainly realized the function
 
1. View fabric v1.0 internal information, such as blocks, transactions, chaincode and so on.
 
2. The load of the statistical system, such as the number of blocks generated per second, the number of blocks generated per minute, transactions generated per second
 
3. Provides a simple REST API that can access the fabric directly through CURL
 
4. Multiple book inquiries 
 
In the future we may expand the following functions
 
1. Operation CHAINCODE , such as install、deploy 、invoker and so on.
2. TLS - based encrypted communication
3. System performance monitoring and alarm
 
 
We hope to continue the development and evolution of blockchain-explorer
 
 
Github:        [https://github.com/onechain/fabric-explorer]
 
demo: [http://112.124.115.82:8800/#|http://112.124.115.82:8800/]

I propose updating the logging to Winston, which would enable logging to file and/or to console, making it much easier to debug the application.

Good logging in turn would make it easier to diagnose problems when using Blockchain Explorer.

Add test cases to it.

column1: Clean Up README Document
column32:
Some links  to get in sync with how hl fabric project is organised: https://bestpractices.coreinfrastructure.org/en/projects/955#analysis

{color:#FF8B00}*IMPORTANT 
-- Docker hub has some links to README file, make sure they are available,  explorer docker images https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/explorer

*{color}



Add 'Notes' at the beginning of the README, the notes should indicate the support of HLFabric per tags of Explorer (need creativity here how to show properly):

Tag     | HLFabric version
v03.9.1 |  HLFabric 1.4
v0.3.9 |   HLFabric 1.4
v03.8 |  HLFabric 1.3
v0.3.7 |  HLFabric 1.2
v0.3.6 |  HLFabric 1.2
v0.3.5 |  HLFabric 1.1
v0.3.4 |  HLFabric 1.1


See attached word document with notes and proposed updates to the README document, which is the entry point for anyone using Hyperledger Explorer.

Document color key:

    *Green Highlight* = Text to add, or a comment.

    *Red Highlight* = Text to delete.

    *Yellow Highlight* = Text to modify.

 

URL of README document:

[https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README.md]

** You can see how other projects in hyperledger are defining README, and use best practices in reorganizing explorer README

column1: Remove package-lock.json from version control
column32: Currently, every commit changes ~ 3000 lines of {{package-lock.json}}. This makes viewing the commit history cumbersome as the {{package-lock.json}} file must be excluded from the diff. {{package-lock.json}} is used by {{npm}} to manage dependencies of the project. Installing dependencies with {{npm install}} will autogenerate this file differently for each user. Therefore, there is no need to track its changes in git. The solution is to remove this file from version control.

column1: Postgres Password ENV Var
column32:
The ENV variable in the Docker-postgres file is set as DATABASE_PASSWORD, however, when the docker container runs it displays this log message:

 
WARNING: No password has been set for the database.
 
After changing the ENV var to: POSTGRES_PASSWORD
 
It works as intended.
 
Was this intended?

column1: CLONE - [java-chaincode] In Chaincode-to-Chaincode invocation, main transaction become successful even if second chaincode invocation fails.
column32:
Lets take a reference to example chaincodes: LinkExample and MapExample.

In LinkExample, we are invoking MapExample chaincode and in put function of MapExample chaincode we are doing some check on number of arguments i.e if the number of arguments is odd then we are throwing an RuntimeException. 

Now, when we invoke LinkExample chaincode with odd number of arguments and it internally invokes MapExample chaincode with same number of arguments then MapExample chaincode throw an RuntimeException and shim layer catch this exception which results in the failure of invoke transaction to MapExample. But the whole transaction (invoke transaction to LinkExample) is getting successful even if when part of the transaction fails. 

In this senario, MapExample is not sending any message regarding its failure to LinkExample which results in success of transaction to LinkExample.
